Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		<n>    - E<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What home entertainment equipment requires cable? Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n>In this exercise you would be given a question such as “in a classroom there are blue chairs green chairs white chairs then you are asked of how many chairs are there? The answer would be 67 as you have 10 blue chirs 20 times as many as blue chairs = 50 green chairs then the difference 13 then there are 67 chairs altogether. You have been asked about home entertainment how many choices there are and only 1 answer would be correct.<n>

You can say that I lived in any building where I lived in the past. If I am no longer living in that place, it is my former home. My home today is the place I live today. The structure that I live in is the place that I currently live. My present home is not the same as the place that I used to live. I do not live in the building I lived in when I was small. I live in my building where the present residents live. I lived in my building when I was living there. I used to live in it. I do not live there anymore.<n>

Choices:  A: carried by people B: guard house C: fly D: follow ultralight airplane E: group together<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input:In an office, there are 7 people. 3 more employees than Bob means that the 3 least in number employees follow Bob. 2 employees more than Bob means that the two least in number employees follow 1 more of the people than Bob. How many people work in the office?<n><n>### Response<n><n>```python<n>Input:In an  office, there are 9 people. 3 more  employees  than Bob means that the<n> 3 least in  number  employees  follow  Bob. 2 employees  more than Bob  means<n>  that the two   least in  number  employes  follow 1 more  of the people  than<n> Bob. How many people  work in the  office?<n>  Answer: 13<n>```<n><n>```python<n>num = int(raw_input())<n><n>if num==0:<n>    print "There are 0 people."<n>elif num<0:<n>    pass<n>elif num%2!=0:<n>    print num*2+1<n>else:<n>    temp = list(raw_input()) # Store all inputs of raw_input() into temp list<n>    for i in range(len(temp)):<n>        if num%2!=0 and temp[i] not in temp:<n>            break<n>    print num*(num/2) if (num%2)!=0 else 1+temp<n>```<n><n>### In the following series, each number is obtained from the preceding number by replacing the last digit by its rank in the English alphabet. For example, 347 replaced by 'E' produces 345.What is the twelfth term?<n>```python<n>Input:"The twelfth term is<n><n>  12,33,97,75,57,94,58,87,89,21,15<n><n>Answer:<n><n>1233977557945887892115"<n><n>```python<n>list = []<n>count = 0<n>if sum(int(line) for line in raw_input().split())==-144:<n>    list = list + ['']<n>    print sum(int(line)-int(line.replace('E', count))-int(line.replace(list[

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:I'm looking for alcohol and fried foods, any suggestions? Choices:  A: pub B: plane C: beer D: store E: fraternity house<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>def friedFoods(r):<n>    if [choice in ['pub', 'plane']]:<n>        print("Alcohol")<n>        r.append('A')<n>        return<n>    if r[0] == 'B':<n>        print("Pub")<n>        r.remove('A')<n>        r.remove(0)<n>        return<n><n>    if r[1] == 'A':<n>        print("Alchohol")<n>        r.add('A')<n>        del r[0]<n>        return<n>    else:<n>        if r[1]!= 'B' and r[1]!='C' and r[1].isdigit():<n>            if r[1]**2 > r[1]/3:<n>                print("The math is too hard, let's try again")<n>                r.pop()<n>                r.clear()<n>                friedFoods (r)<n>```<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Choose the statement that best answers the question or states the fact you came to. Click your choice or press the _Enter_ key to move on to the next question.<n><n>Part A<n>**Question:**  <n>In what way do the blue and yellow circles combine?<n><n>**Choices:**  <n>1.The blue circle has an area of 92 square paces, and the yellow circle has an area of.9 square paces. The total area of the two circles is 93.<n>2.The blue circle has more area than the yellow circle.<n>3.The blue circle has less area than the yellow circle by one square space.<n>4.The blue circle has half the area of the yellow circle.<n><n>**Answer:**  <n>I think that they have combined their shapes into a blue and yellow circle because ______________.<n><n>Part B<n>**Question:** Which triangle is equivalent to the shaded triangle?<n><n>**Choies:**  <n>1.The small triangle with one square space.<n>2.The medium triangle with two square spaces.<n>3.The large triangle with three square spaces.<n>4.The small triangle with two square spaces<n><n>**Answer: **I think that ___________ is the shaded triangle because __________________.<n><n>Part C<n>**Question:** Choose the statement that correctly completes the sentence.<n><n>My favorite color is ___________________.<n><n>**Choies :**<n><n>1. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Someone lacking immortality will one day be? Choices:  A: kick the bucket B: mortal C: dead D: can die E: dying<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>"Kick the bucket", which the response will be B.<n>```<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>If the person is immortal, there is no chance that he/she would be "died". So we will choose 'will be' to be B in the sentence. Other choices such as 'be can', 'be mortal', 'be dead', 'be dying' which will be incorrect as we have to be sure that mortal and dead are not true in this case.<n><n>```<n>Someone lacking immory: A: die B: immortal, C: be dead, D: be dying<n>```<n><n>### Input How many times does 39 go into 190? There are no fractions.<n>Answer: 5. No negative numbers <n>

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What enables most people to transport themselves? We used those requests and provided what was required. <n><n><n><n><n>### How Do We Do It? - Writing<n><n>In response to a problem like this, first we read the given task and then break it down into steps, we try to understand the problem and then try to figure out what the question wants from us.<n><n>### In this example: We were given two problems to write responses.<n>1. Input: What do dogs eat?<n>2. Input: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n><n>Then we apply the steps of the writing process to try to generate more appropriate responses.<n><n>### STEP 1 - READING & UNDERSTANDING<n><n>Read the instructions for the problem multiple times to try to understand it.<n><n>### The Task:<n>We were given multiple tasks to apply the steps of the Writing Process to try to generate more responses that appropriately completes each request, but for now we will write responses to the instructions without the help of the steps of the Writing process.<n><n>### THE PROMPT:<n>Below is an instruction that describes the task with no guidance<n><n>Write a response that appropriately  completes the request. <n><n><n>### Instructoin:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:i like to examine different things,why do books the chapters on the back Choices:  A: examine thing B: go somewhere C: knit D: read book E: see particular program<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Choice A:**  <n>In order to examine something, you first need to put something behind the back.  <n>It goes like this:  <n>Examine <--> Put behind the back (something)<n><n>**Choice B:**  <n>In [a](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/go-to) the chapters are on the [back](https://www.google.com/search?q=%22books%20on%20the%20back%22&oq=%22books+on-the+back%22+OR+%22back+on%20their%22&aqs=chrome.0.57j69i62j37j49i448.7334j4j1&sourceid=chrome&es_sm=93&ie=UTF-8) books the [chapter](https://www.dictionary.com/browse/chapter?s=t)s are on the [backs](https://www.etymonline.com/word/back) of the pages.<n><n>**Choice C:**  <n>To knit something, you need to first examine different things.  <n>It goes something like this.<n><n>**Choice D:**  <n>To read a book you first must examine the book.<n><n>**Choice E:**  <n>To watch a particular program, first you need to examine it.  <n>It goes similar to the first choices, although the process is reversed.<n><n>### Input :  <n>I have the following input:<n>Input:The cost of your ticket goes up 17 dollars when you go over 5 hours<n><n>Input:I live here<n><n>Response:<n><n>### Instructions:Provide the correct response to the input. <n><n>### Input 1:<n>The cost of your ticket _________ _ when you go over 3 hours.<n><n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Explain the correct code in terms of a human response.<n><n>### Choice 1:<n>The correct code is a command:<n><n>```<n>TicketCost++<n>```<n><n>This is because the first choice adds an increase of 17 dollars to all tickets that have been purchased before the purchase of the ticket.<n><n>###

Choices:  A: growing older B: reproducing C: shuddering D: perspiration E: palpitations<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input:\nTeach: In order to determine each variable's individual value and then its collective value, students are able to count the number of blue chairs, green chair, and white chairs in a room by using the total number of chairs as the product.<n>The first step in determining the average number of cats is to determine the range using the formula below.<n><n>Range = Lower Bound Number - Upper Bound Number<n><n>The formula for this task requires an explanation of which chairs do not fit into the category of blue chairs or green chairs, white chairs, or both.<n>This is because of the difference between the variables and values in this formula.<n>The same is true for the average number of sheep in all four categories of sheep.<n>The formula for the average number of cat is also used in the task.<n><n>### Input\nSuggestion:The purpose of this task is to determine the average number of sheep that the farmer would have to count each day.<n>Each category (sheep, cats, and other animals) should be averaged separately and then combined into one average. Then the categories of sheep should be combined into a second average.<n>This would give the farmer the average number of sheep per day.<n><n>### Response:\nIt is possible to use this formula to determine the average number for each category of sheep.<n>However, the purpose of this task is not to determine the average number per category of sheep.<n>Instead, the purpose of this formula is to find how many sheep are in each category.<n><n>### Comment:<n>A task that describes what is to be done in this task and gives a response is provided.<n>Answer to this task is correct<n><n>### Instructions<n><n><table style="margin-top:15px"><n>  <thead><n>  <tr><n>    <th colspan="7">1.What is the largest prime number in 235 to 259?”<n>  </th><n>  </tr><n>  </thead><n>  <tbody><n>  <tr style="border-bottom:solid"><n>    <td><n>      <pre><n>        Input: What are 8 and 18 greater than 235?<n>      </pre><n>    </td><n>    <td>Input: Choices:

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where is a paper notice likely to be left on a house? Choices:  A: front door B: conference C: classroom D: refrigerator E: suitcase<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think that a paper notice will be likely left on a refrigerator.<n><n>### Reasoning:<n>The paper notice is likely to be left on the refrigerator. A, B and C are wrong because those are common places in a household as indicated by the question. D is wrong because the refrigerator probably has a common spot in every household so it is not a choice. E is wrong because it is an inappropriate place to leave a paper notice. There is no common household place where a paper notice can be left. Hence, it is the only thing that makes sense.<n><n>### Input Incorrectly<n><n>1.<n>> 1. A: front door B<n>> 2. B: conference C: classe C: classroom D<n>> E: suitcase<n> <n>### Valid<n><n>3.<n>> 1, A 2, B 3, C<n> <n>## Input and Response<n><n>1. Please be specific and accurate.<n><n>Input: Janet needs to move 3 times as many pounds as Joe in order to be as strong. Brenda weighed 4 times as much as Janet, and Mary was 1.5 times as heavy as Brenda. How much does Mary weigh?<n><n>Response: Mary weighed 24 pounds.<n><n> <n>### Correct response<n><n>I've added a few more words to the task instruction, but the result is still the same!<n><n> <n>## Input Incorrectly<n>1. <n>> 1. Where will Janet weigh more, even if Joe weighs the same? Choices: A: at Brenda's house B: at Mary's house C: at the post office<n>7. <n>> 7. Where will Mary weigh more, even Brenda? Choices: A. At Brenda's house C. At the post office<n><n>### Valid<n>1.<n>> Where will Janet weighe more, even if Joe weights the same choice A: at Brenda house<n>2.<n>> Where will Mary weighe more even if Brenda weighe 32 pounds C.  At the post office<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Mary wasn't familiar with James, so she wasn't comfortable speaking with him. How might she come off? Choices:  A: cold B: unfamiliar C: unknown D: unacquainted E: shy<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Explanation:<n>1. "coming off" is the idiom for the impression you make on others. <n>2. In (B), the expression "come off" has the figurative meaning "be perceived as."<n>2. In (E), the expression "come on" has the figurative meanings, as in "Get on with it" and "Let's get on with it."<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Input<n>Mary was unfamiliar with James, so she was uncomfortable speaking with him.<n><n>What word best completes this sentence?<n>Choices:<n><n>a. unfamiliar<n>b. familiar<n>c. comfortable<n>d. uncomfortable<n>e. cold<n><n>### Response<n>e.<n><n>### Exaimation:<n>1. (B) describes the way the sentence is written, which is (C). (E) is the way the sentence is spoken, as in "Get with it." (A) is an answer choice because it means unfriendly or antagonistic ("being cold in a room, for example").  (D) is the most literal reading of the sentence ("wasn't," which does not require the past participle, is not the most common). (B) does not fit the sentence well, and if (E) is the answer, then the question is incorrect.<n>2. "Come on, Mary. Let's get on with this," James might say, where the correct answer choice to the question would be (A), which means "disagreeable" or "cold."<n><n>### Input <n>"How can she make that judgment on me?" she demanded.<n><n>### Response <n>How can she judge?<n><n>### Examination:<n>1. "make that judgment" is a phrase (A), which means, literally, "judge that." The past participle of the verb is necessary; (B) is the closest verb, except that it would not be correct in context. (C) and (D) are not the phrases ("make" is not used in that way in normal English syntax or semantics, and "judge" means something else in that sentence). If "judge" means "judge" in this context, then "judge" is not

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Bill did not abandon the fight, but did what to the enemy? Choices:  A: arrogate B: retain C: embrace D: smile E: engage<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>@echo off<n>    Title = %~dp0\..\..\..\SOLUTION %~n0<n><n>    if %n% == 0 goto:start<n><n> :start<n>    setlocal<n>    echo Title = %~dp%0<n>    (goto B)<n><n>:B<n>    if %1% == "A" goto:A<n>    if %1%% == "A" gotto:A<n>    if /I {%1%%} == "A" got to:A<n>:A<n>    if "%1" == "A" got:A<n><n>:C<n>    if %1== "B" got:C<n><n>:D<n>    if %1 == "B" got:D<n><n>:E<n>    if %1 %% == "B" goto:E<n>    if {%1%%} ==  "B" got to:E<n>:E<n>    :F<n><n>    if %1%= "C" got:F<n>    if "%1%= "C" gave:F<n>    if {%1%= "C"} goto:F<n><n>:F<n>    if %1 %== "C" gave:G<n>    if %1=% "C" given:G<n><n>:G<n>    if/I {%1%= "D"} == goto G<n>    if {%1%= "D" goto:G<n><n>:H<n>    echo Hello!<n><n>(goto :start<n>)<n><n>end local<n><n>:end<n>exiting... <n>```<n>

When trying to solve a problem, you need to figure out which concepts need to be identified and what formula you need to apply to get the desired solution.<n><n>3.  Always answer each question exactly as it is written.<n><n>#### Example:<n>Write a sentence which correctly completes what the question says.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If I have a vintage, decorative light source in my possession, what is it likely to be? Choices:  A: sun B: sky C: candle D: house E: lamp<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n>### Explaination:<n>A, B, C, D: Sky, sun, candle, and lamp, respectively, are in the sky.<n>Only E, the vintage, decorated lamp is on a light source (i.e. not the sky).<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The instruction describes a task. Write up the response that accurately and appropriately completes the task.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: A company hired a programmer for 600 us dollars.  A year later, they paid her 4000 us dollars. A year after that,  they paid her over 36000 us dollars for 12000 hours more of programming.  To the nearest dollar, how much did the programmer earn in total?<n>Answer: 413600<n><n>### Demo2:<n>Input: A year after the birth in 1996 of her baby brother, her sister celebrated her birthday by going to the movies and having cake with her. How many years older than her baby brother was she that day?<n>Answer: 9 years<n><n>### Demo3:<n>Input: 7 times the distance between two points in a coordinate plane.<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Write out a response, in the correct format, to following questions, to the nearest dollar. To the nearest dollar means the response should contain answers ending in 0 or 5 in the units place, and 0, 5, or 99 in the whole number place (e.g., 1400, 1500, or 199). Write your response in C and in C++.<n><n>### Exploiation:<n><n>In this solution, a program will be written to solve the problem of calculating the answers to a multiple choice question for the given multiple choice question problem and the requested number of attempts is only 1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The movie had many a song and dance, it was a what? Choices:  A: bollywood B: record C: musical D: jukebox E: napster<n><n>### Response:		<n>The movie was a jukebox.<n><n>### Reference<n>https://rosettacode.org/wiki/Multiplication_table#C_and_Python<n>> The task is to write a function that, when passed the indices of two positive integers, calculates the value of the product of those integers. If I am told that the function take (3,4), then the function will return 12, for example.<n><n><n>### Python Solution:<n><n>    def multiplication_table(i,j):<n>      <n>       for x in range(i+1,j+1):<n>             print()<n>       print(x)<n>    for i in range(2,10):<n>            for j in range(5,10):<n>                print('{:5d} * {:5d} ={:5}'.format(i,j,i*j))<n>    x = input('For how many pairs?')<n>            x = int(x)<n>            for i in range(1,x+1):<n>                for j in range(1, x):<n>                    print('{:5d}'*i,'*{:5d}'.format(i*x,j*x))<n>                    for m in range(1,5):<n>                    print(j+m)<n><n><n>### Output:<n>For how many pairs?<n>6<n><n>     5  7  10   15  20   25<n>      6  9  15  21 28   36<n>    11  17  23  31  41 49<n>   13  19  27  39  53 61<n>   16  22  30  42  56 70<n>   18  24  32  48  66 84<n>   20  26  34  50  69 90<n><n>      1  8  21  29 36   45<n>      2  10  24  31 40   50<n>      3  12  27  34 48   61<n>      4  14  29  37 51   64<n>      5  16  31

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:An attempt to confirm an applicant's reference would fail if the reference does what? Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>#### Code:<n><n>```python<n>import itertools as it<n>i=0<n><n>while i<44:<n>    guess=int(input("try to guess: "))<n>    if guess<44:<n>        i+=1<n>    elif guess>44:<n>        print(guess,'is out of list.')<n>    try:<n>        print(int(it.permutations(list(range(44)),guess)[0]))<n>    except:<n>        print("error")<n>```<n><n>#### Output:<n><n>Input:Guess the number in which the following list contains.<n><n>```text<n>try to guess:<n>5 <n>error<n>try to guess: <n>6 <n>try to guess:  <n>2<n>try to guess:   <n>1<n>try to guess:     <n>0<n>try to guess:    <n>3 <n>try to guess<n>4 <n>try to guess    <n>6<n>try to guess:          <n>5<n>try to guess:        <n>7<n>try to guess:         <n>0<n>try to guide:         <n>4<n>error<n>try to guide:        <n>5 <n>try guide:             <n>1<n>try guide:              <n>7         <n>try guide:              0<n>try to guide         :     6         5      2   1         5 <n>try guide :       9     3         0 <n>```<n>###Instruction:Write a program in which you define a variable containing a string. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What happens when you take a shower after going for a run? Choices:  A: feeling refreshed B: becoming tired C: restlessness D: leg cramps E: sweating<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>  #import<n>  import pandas as pd<n>  df = pd.DataFrame(columns= ['A','B','C','D','E'])<n><n>  #Instruction<n>  df['A'] = 3<n>  df['B'] = 2<n>  df['C'] = 5<n>  df['D'] = 7<n>  df['E'] = 6<n><n>  #Display<n>  print(df)<n>  df.style.apply(lambda x: 'BOLD' if x == 2 else 'STRIKETHROUGH' if x == 0 else 'REGULAR', font_size=25).to_file('out.txt', encoding = "utf-8", mode = "w")<n><n>  #Pictures<n>  df.head(1).to_html(file_name='df.png')<n>  df.tail(1).to_png(file_name='dft.png')<n><n>  #Data manipulation<n>  df['A'].apply(lambda x:  [sum(x),min(x),max(x)])<n><n>  #Creating a new data frame based on df<n>  dfc = df['A'].apply(-1)<n>  dfc = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(dfc)<n>  dfc.head()<n>  dfc<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: bad feelings B: confusion C: going to court D: hurt feelings E: sandwiches<n><n>### Response:		<n>Civil action is bringing a lawsuit against someone. Someone could file Civil action for slander, harassment, or some other reason. The hurt feelings option isn’t correct because hurt feelings can arise from any situation. Having “bad” feelings also isn’t correct because a bad feeling can be caused by other things that aren’t lawsuits. Having confusion is also correct because sometimes you may not know what to do after filing a civil lawsuit.<n><n>### Extensions<n><n>- Write a program that asks a user a multiple choice question. Community<n><n>### Input 3:<n><n>## The goal of the project is to provide a tool for a teacher to check their students' logic skills. The teachers will use the tool to review the answers provided by their students.<n><n>### Rationale<n>Since we are creating a tool for a specific user, there are several things in the instruction we will have to consider. <n><n>- We need to ensure that the tool can provide an instruction for the correct answer of each question. <n><n>- The answers of the tool should be checked if the logic skill of the students have reached a particular standard. The standard will be defined by the user of the tool.<n><n><n>## Steps to Implement the tool<n><n>### User input<n><n>1. The teacher will submit the test they want to be assessed by selecting it from his/her computer. <n> <n>2. The tool checks the answers the teacher submits. The answers are checked using the logic instruction provided in the tool. If the teacher enters an answer of which the logic instruction is not satisfied, the teacher will be notified immediately. <n>  <n>    * Ex. The answer the teacher selects and the instruction 2(3)1=6 do not match<n><n>3. If the answers are matched with the logic instruction, the tool notifies the instructor that the answer matches the instruction.<n><n>### Response <n><n>Since this is a tool used in the classroom, we expect users to submit more than one set of answers.<n><n>In general, the teacher selects a group of students that have the same grade and has the same number of questions.<n><n>Then they submit the test.<n><n>After the teacher submitted the test, the tool will provide the students' logical answers. If the answers do not match the logic instruction, the teacher will be aware of the student's logical thinking skill.<n><n><n>### Instructions for 2018<n><n>Write a response based on the provided instructions. Answer the question by writing one complete sentence. Use complete sentences only; do not submit partial responses or respond with only a question.<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Describe any information not covered in class. You may not rely on class discussions, lecture, textbook or your own personal opinions to respond.<n><n>### Submit

How many chairs does the classroom have when you include:<n>3 tables, 10 blue chains and 6 white chairs?<n><n>Answer: [How can i determine the number of chairs in the classroom with the given clues?](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/65677808/how-can-i-determine-the-number-of-chairs-in-the-classroom-with-the-given-clues)<n>I answered this question by taking the clues written down and creating a nested for loop (for example: n = total amount of chairs in the room)  If user input is given for each chair it is multiplied by the value of the loop. And then the amount of user input is taken (user input is taken here because I used 25 for chair and 30 for table in my question) if the user input is 25 the number of chairs and tables should add up to 55).

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What  might john order at an indian resturant on top of the space needle? Choices:  A: large city B: seattle C: curry D: clothing E: reservation<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If I were John, I would order the following:<n><n>D: curry<n>C: Curry<n>B: Seattle<n>A: large city<n><n>This is because if you take away the clothing items away then all you have left is the curry and the city. Since the order is in the reverse alphabetical order, John would not be able to get any other curry or city if he only has one choice, so he would have to eat the one curry and one city he has. This is because if there was a choice of both the curry and city after the clothing items, then John would automatically get it that way.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a hairbrush along with bandages? Choices:  A: drugstore B: hospital C: bedroom D: car E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>I believe an answer would be “B-Hospital”. The only places I can think of where someone would buy a bandage along with a hair brush would be in a hospita;l of course in the “hospital” section. A hospital has things such as band-aids and medications that need to be used, or at least that’s what I think of when I think of a hospital. I can only think of a drugstore that could sell a hairbrush; I don’t think of band-aids in this case. I also don’t think off a place where you would get a hairbrush and band-aids would be on a car. I don’t know if a hairbrush would sell in a car or not, but I don’t think a place where you would buy band-aids is in a car. I really think an answer would be “E-House” as well, but I think that a car can have something like that, but the hospital is best. I don’t think that you would go out on a car and say get me a brush AND a band-aid, so I am not going to choose that one.<n><n>### Input<n>There were 450 candy bars in the box, 3 quarters of them were orange, and 5% were chocolate. The other 92% of the candy bars were made from neither vanilla cream nor fudge. How many chocolate and fudge milk chocolate bars were there in the box?<n><n>### Response<n><n>26 was my answer, but I chose 28. I would be interested in hearing answers to answer this problem from other people.<n><n>### Why Your Answers were right/incorrect/helpful<n>I think my answers would be right because they are the most similar. Other people will probably answer in a different order and choose different answers. I think my answers are wrong because they are not the correct percentage. If we are going to choose the answer based on the percentage then what is the best way to figure it out, I wonder if there is a mathematical equation or even a more simple way to figure it out. I think people will find this question to be a difficult question since it is asking about a 5% and 92% and we are not told what kind of percentage that is it’s

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would a restaurant put a candle? Choices:  A: dimly lit room B: kitchen C: wall D: table E: birthday cake<n><n>### Response:		dimly lit room<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A: It describes an area that has very low lighting, which typically happens in dark kitchens.<n>B: It describes an area where the heat is on and thus it creates smoke, hence it is found in kitchens.<n>C: It describes an area used by waiters while serving and the like, thus it is in the dining area or table.<n>D: It describes an area on birthdays to mark the occasion, hence it is where they are placed, on birthday cakes.<n>E: It describes a room used at night to light the place, thus it indicates the hallway or the dining area.<n>### Write a comment for each question. Answer correctly and adequately.<n>### Input: How many pizza shops does Cindy own?<n>Answer: 4<n>### What is the sum of the numbers in the sequence 55. 40. 35. 30?<n><n>### Input : Mara has twice as may cards as Janet.<n>### What is true about this expression: 9 x 1= 50<n><n>### Input Birthday cake<n>### What is another room in the restaurant to place a candle<n><n>### Input The sum of numbers in sequence is<n>\end{code}<n><n>Comment: Your code works properly<n><n>Comment: How do i make the correct answer?<n><n>Answer: It is possible to write as below :<n><n>\begin{code}<n>import java.util.*;<n><n>class Stack1<n>{<n>    public static String getAnswer(int[] num)<n>    {<n>        String s= "+";  // String for "+".<n><n>        int i= num.length-1; //To get the length, consider -1 for last index.<n><n>        for( int j=0; i>j; j++) //Iterate from begining of array till ( j<=i).<n>            if(num[j]==num[j+1]) //If any number present in array equal to its next number.<n>                s=s + "\nERROR\n";<n>                return (s+"");//returns a string like "ERROR".<n>        else{<n>           return (s+num[0]+" " +num[num.length-1]); //All numbers are

You may assume that all 10 employees are present and working each day.<n><n>### The program must print the total salary paid out for the week. The total must be a floating point number. If the total is greater than 10000, you must print a string (ex: 10234)<n><n>### Input must be in a text file.<n><n>### Input file format:<n><n>### First line is 10 numbers corresponding to weeks (0 to 9)<n><n>### Last line is 10 float numbers containing the total number of hours worked for each employee for those same weeks<n><n>- You may assume that the hours worked each week by each employee is a valid floating point number (ex: 48.37)<n><n>### Example Input:<n><n>### Example output:<n><n>### #include <iostream><n><n>int main() {<n>    int weeks;<n><n>    std::ifstream inFile("Payroll.txt");<n><n>    if (inFile.fail()) {<n>        std::cout << "Error in file opening";<n>        return 1;<n>    }<n><n>    std::cout << "Please enter the number of weeks: ";<n>    <n>    inFile >> weeks;<n><n>    if(weeks < 0)<n>    {<n>        std::cerr << "Invalid number of weeks, program crashing";<n>        return 0;<n>    }<n>    <n>    std::cout<<"Entering payroll information for weeks: "<<weeks;<n>    <n>    for(int i = 0 ; i < weeks ; i++)<n>    {<n>        int a, b;<n>        // Increment<n>        a++;<n>    }<n>     inFile.close();<n>    system("pause");<n>    return 0;<n>}<n>

Choices:  A: apartment B: table C: school D: office E: house<n><n>### Response:		In this context, a computer is an electronic device that computes, often with a display and sometimes an input device.<n><n>### Input<n><n>A computer that is located in a residence is a home computer,  A computer that is located in or on a desk or workbench is a desktop computer, while one located in a server room is a server computer.<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>A computer that has a tablet form factor, in a small, portable, lightweight, and in some cases handheld design, is called a tablet computer. Tablet computers usually work with a touch screen, and can run a complete operating system. The first tablet computer was the 1983 IBM Personal Computing System, but Apple's iPad is by far the most common form. A tablet computer can contain a display, key pad, and speakers.<n>In an enterprise setting, a computer is put into a device management system for data storage,  but usually in order to run a full-desktop operating system.<n>Computers can be located in mobile devices such as telephones, hand-held games, personal digital assistants, games consoles, digital cameras, MP3 players, digital televisions, smart appliances such as coffee machines and smart thermostats.<n><n>### Reference<n><n>https://www.quora.com/Which-device-would-you-put-a-computer-other-than-a-desk-A-apartment-B-table-C-school-D-office-or-E-house?share=1<n>

Select the best answer and demonstrate each answer.<n><n>### Question :<n>Which of the following will produce the same solution 52 = -1 and (977-51) = -8<n><n>### Answer :<n><n>For each problem solve the subtraction first.<n><n>### A.<n>977 = -51<n><n>The difference is 926.<n><n>926 = -292<n><n>The difference is negative 634.<n><n>-634 = 18<n><n>The difference between 18 and 634 = - 616.<n><n>The difference is -616.<n>Since each difference is negative, the difference between the subtractions will be negative too.<n>-52 = -634.<n>Therefore, all the answers to the problems will produce -1.<n><n>## Question:What is 172 + (-34) x 42<n><n>## Answer:<n>42 x 172 = 7064.<n><n>Since 34 is negative, the answer is negative.<n><n>## Question :What is 594 % (-82

The first input is given by the user, the number of days he needs to calculate how many kilometers traveled and the price they will pay if they need to rent a car for a day.<n>The second input is that of their salary they earn on a month and the third one is the cost of parking their car in their area.<n>The last input, we cannot change it because it is given in the case statement, it is the number of days a month has.<n><n>### The problem to be solved:<n><n>The user is given their salary and it will divide it by 30 to get their monthly salary. We will use the monthly salary to calculate how much they can pay for a parking permit, which can't be more than 30. We will subtract 30 from their monthly salary that is left is from the permits they bought.<n>After that, we will calculate the cost price of the car rent, in this case: 80. We will subtract the cost of the permit bought to know the left amount of money that will be spent when they buy a car.<n>The next step is to take the price they will pay for a day and multiply it by the days they have left to know the total price they have to pay for the whole day.<n>If the result is greater than the money they have left to know how much more they have to add to the amount of remaining money.<n>### The program:<n>```java<n><n>public class Renter<n><n>{<n>    public static void main(String[] args)<n>    {<n>        int userSalary;<n>        int permitPrice;<n>        int priceCarRent = 80;<n>        int rent = rent * 10;<n><n>        if(args.length == 3)<n>        {<n>        Double.parseDouble(args[2]);<n>        }<n>        else<n>        {<n>        System.out.println("Wrong number of arguments.Please input argument 1, day1, day2...then you enter your salary monthly, the price of cost parking and the cost of renting a car.Then the cost of permits will be calculated");<n>        System.exit(

Let's look at the verbs. What verb is given first? The first verb is "is an adult": is used to _be_ or _to have_ a specific characteristic. Follow these steps to help create your complete task.<n><n>1. Describe a task that your user should accomplish using our application. The task should be specific and provide information about the user input and the expected output.<n>1. Provide a short solution to the task. If there is more than one solution, provide at least one solution.<n>1. Provided an example of the input and the expected output using a problem described in the example.<n><n>### Rubric:<n><n>To get full credit on a scaffold, you must complete all of the following:<n><n>* Complete the steps in the scaffolding instructions to write an instruction based on the task given.<n>* Create an appropriate solution to the instruction.<n>* Create at least one example of an input to the solution and the resulting expected output. <n><n>For the scaffoldings above, your scaffold should include all of the following: <n><n>* Instruction, with at least one short solution to the task written at the start of the instruction.<n>* One solution (you're free to include additional solutions too)<n>* At least one example of input and output.<n><n>Your scaffold should not include sections that are not required by the rubric, or are the same as the examples above.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What should you do if your pens aren't work? Choices:  A: ink in B: caps C: ink cartridges D: take notes E: scribble<n><n>### Response:		(C)<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Answers (A) and (E) are incorrect because pens do not work if you do not have ink. It is also incorrect to say that you'd need to write if a pen didn't work. A and E are examples of word problems.<n><n>Choices (B), (C) and (D) are all correct or acceptable. You can remove one cap and put it back on a pen to replace an empty ink cartridge. If a pen doesn't work, you can take notes.<n>

There are 22 people in a group who are about the same age. If there are twice as many men as women, and there are twice as many children as men, how many people are there under age 40?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>```<n>Input 1: Males = 12<n>Females = 8<n><n>Input 2: Males under age 40 = 5<n>Females under age 4 = 2<n>Children under age 1 = 2<n>Total under age 1 =5<n><n>Output: There are 22 (12+8) people in a group who  are about the same age<n><n>So, there must be 13 people under age 40<n><n>```<n><n>### Input<n>The number X<n><n>### Demos:<n>```<n>X = 7<n><n>X ^ 2 = 49<n>X ^ ½ = 7<n>X ^ ¼ = 3<n>X ^ 1/8 = 1<n><n>```<n><n><n><n><n><n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Why might someone want to be buying beer? Choices:  A: satisfaction B: good feelings C: complications D: feel good about yourself E: stress<n><n>### Response:		<n>### This is the response.<n>### It can be given as a sentence and a formula.<n>### To use either, write the formula or enter a question mark.<n>### If there is more than one answer, use commas to separate the answers.<n>### The input can be a question.<n>### If the input is a question and there is only one answer, do not write a question mark.<n><n>### Example:<n>Input:  Danny hated helping people<n><n>### Output:<n><n>### This is how the response is generated if the input is question.<n><n>## Answer:  Stress<n><n>### Otherwise, the formula is used.<n><n>### Input formula:<n><n>### If any answer is missing, write a question mark.  If there is more than 1 answer, write the answers separated with commas.<n><n>### The question will generate the formula and enter the formula.<n><n>## Example:<n><n>## Input: Danny hated helping <n><n>## Output: <n><n>## Above is the task description.<n><n>## How can you generate this formula?<n><n>## Write a program that generates the formula.<n>

Choices:  A: gathering of information B: communication C: feel relaxed D: kill boredom E: social bonding<n><n>### Response:		<n>    A: The person is trying to gather information by chatting with friends. If chatting with friends accomplishes, it is easy for people to make new friends.<n><n>### Input :  <n>There are 8 pennies in a cup. Dale takes 2 pennies without looking. How many are left?<n><n>### Response :<n>    There are 6 pennies in a. cup. Dale takes two pennies without looking, and there are 4 pennies in all.<n><n>### Solution : <n>8p - 2 = 6p in a cup<n><n>### Input2 : What is a person chatting<n><n>With friends typically trying to accomplish? Choices are:  A: gather useful information B: Communication C: kill boredom D: social connection E: social bonding,<n><n>### Response2:<n><n>Person who chatting with a friend, what he hopes to do it collect information, chat to relax<n><n>### Input3<n><n>In a classroom, there <n><n>Blue chairs, green chains, white chairs. There 10 blue chains. Green chains are 3 times as much as the blue chairs. The White chairs are less than the green chains and blue chains. How many chairs in a classroom<n><n>## Solve :<n>10*(3) + 13 = 67<n>Because green chains are 3 and times than the blue chairs. So, the green chains are 4 times than the blue chains.<n><n>### Additional Info:<n>This task was created by a community member who isn't part of the Google Docs team. Choices:  A: near B: closeness C: here D: proximity E: this<n><n>### Response:		<n>The response should be a single word or a short sentence. It may not include a question mark or exclamation mark. Spellings are not important.<n><n>### Example:<n>The sensor would just the (a)proximity, of course. You could call it that too. I would like it and my children to be (b)proximity, at all time. Don’t come close! - Mavis<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: How to you define success? How do you define failure?<n>Answer: The success is that you live your life happily by the day and you learn to live in the moment. There is no success with an empty stomach.<n><n>Answer: The failure is that you regret and that your happiness will not be your best memories. There is no failure with an empty stomatch.<n><n>### Response<n>The response should be concise and to the point. Spellings are acceptable. Excessive sentence length is discouraged.<n><n>### Examples:<n>“It’s a lot easier to find joy in others when your heart is open. It’s a lot easier that too.”<n><n>“A smile is the best thing that could have come out of a face, but sometimes one needs a change.”<n><n>### Comment:<n>You may ask for clarity or a simpler explanation than that required in the question.<n><n>## Assessment<n>I know my assessment, but I would like someone to re-assess it.<n><n><n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people doing jumping jacks? Choices:  A: military base B: opera C: water fountain D: bus stop E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Instructions:<n>* Enter an answer in A, B, C, D, or E. If you enter nothing, or if you enter more than one answer, you will lose marks.<n>* If you enter more than one choice but it is written correctly, you will get full marks.<n>* If it is not written correctly, the letter will be marked wrong.<n><n>### Student:<n>### Instructional response:<n>A. Military base because soldiers are there and they are doing military exercise<n><n>### Response with error:<n><n>### Instructions with error:<n>A: military base<n>B: opera<n>C: water fountains<n>D: bus stop<n>E: church<n><n><n>### Student response with error:<n>C: water founatains<n><n>### Instructor response<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Can you name a good reason for attending school? Choices:  A: get smart B: boredom C: colds and flu D: taking tests E: spend time<n><n>### Response:		The best reason for me attending school is to take test.<n><n>## :point_right: Solution<n>```java<n>class Person<n>{<n>	public static boolean moreThan(int a, int b)<n>	{<n>		return a > b;<n>	}<n><n>	public static int sum(int a, int  i)<n>	{<n>        if(moreThan(a, i))<n>        {<n>            a+= (i-1);<n>        }<n>        else<n>        {<n>            i+= (a-1);<n>        // i must be smaller than a<n>         }<n>         return a+i;  <n>    }<n>}<n><n>public class Exercise035_03<n>{<n>	public enum Choices { A, B, C, D, E };<n>	// we can choose to use enum <n>	// to represent the class choices<n>	static class Choice<n>	{<n>	   static private int getNumber(Choices a)<n>		{<n>			if(a== Choices.A)<n>			{<n>	 		return 0;<n>			}<n>			else if(a== Choices,B)<n>				return 1;<n>			else <n>				// i can use switch to get this<n>				<n>				if(choices.D)<n>			 		return -2;<n>				else if (choices.E)<n>			   		return -3;<n><n>			return 2;<n>		}<n>	}<n>	public static void main(String[] args)<n>	{<n><n>	}<n>}<n><n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:She needs to visit a bookshop after buying the latest fashion, where should she look? Choices:  A: student union B: mall C: department store D: library E: town or city<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>There is an instruction above and a demonstration after.<n><n>This exercise is a type of arithmetic equation. It would show how to solve different equation by finding the values of different characters.<n><n>The type of values and expression are different and we got to show the correct result for every equation.<n><n>### Response<n><n>The answer is B because it is 3 times as many is 32.<n><n>150=2×150+40 <br><n>The numbers after the "=" sign is called expression, so we have a=150 after the =" ".<br><n>We can see that the two numbers on the right are the same, so when we add two of them together we can get the result. <br><n>So, 2×150 = 150+450 <br><n>And so 150=2(450).<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Your task.<n><n>-   Write a statement that you should do to finish this task correctly.<n>-   Write how many times you should perform the same task.<n>-   Write the answer of the task.<n>-   In your answer write a sentence that describes how and the reason of your solution.<n><n>*For example:- the expression is 3 times as much as a number*<n><br><n>*Input:- in a classroom there are blue chairs green chairs and white chairs. there are 10 blue cha*<n><br>*the green chairs are 4 times as many as the blu*<n><n>### Feedback.<n><n>*Correct solution*-<n>Because the white chairs are 4 less than the blue and green chairs.<n><n>*Incorrect solution *-<n>A because 10=2(20)<n><n>-Write why did you think this solution was not correct.<n>

How many numbers can you pick?<n><n>### Answer:<n>The answer is zero, because:<n><n>The quotient is greater than three.<n><n>The number must be greater than zero.<n><n>The sum is between 1 and 2.5<n><n>### Input1<n>If you add three numbers, and one of the numbers is 10 less than the sum, the sum is 190. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What will happen to skin pinched in something? Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		<n>>A B C D E<n><n>Input:If 5 gallon jugs of milk and juice are mixed together to make a gallon of mix, how many gallons of milk and juice must be in the mix?<n>Answer: 3 gallons of juice, 2 gallons of milk<n><n>Input:If you are at sea level (0 feet), then at what height is the pressure in the air equal to 2 pounds for every 5 pounds of your body weight?<n>Answer: 0.8 miles<n><n>Input: If it takes a full minute for an elevator that travels at 70 miles per hour to stop at a floor, how far will the elevator have travelled in one minute?<n>Answer: 1400 meters<n><n>Input: If one car travels 50 miles per hour and another car travels 70 miles per day, which car travels faster, in miles per day?<n>Answer: Both travel at 75 miles per day

the 1st argument is an integer<n>+ - the 2nd is a double<n>+ - the 3rd is a string<n>+ - The method should take in the 3 arguments and in turn print to the screen what its type is (integer, double and string)<n>+ - When the user enters an empty string, the method should print to the screen, “that is not a number”<n>+ - The method will iterate over the 3 arrays and print their values to the screen also<n><n>#### Input:<n>1) Integer 2) Double 3) String<n><n>#### Response:<n>```<n>Integer: 1<n>Double: 2.1<n>String: that is not a number<n><n>```<n><n>#### Input: <n>1) Integer 3) Double -1.0<n><n>#### Response: <n>```<n>Not a number: String<n>Null<n>```<n><n>#### Instructions: Write the following code that compares the two numbers using the equals and or operators.<n>+ - create a method that takes 2 numbers with no parameters<n>+ - use the equals method and return a boolean<n>+ - the boolean should be True if they are equals and false if they are not<n>+ - create a test case using a method and its parameters<n><n>#### Response: ```<n>1==1<n>false<n><n>2==2<n>true<n>```<n><n>#### Output:<n>```<n>java.lang.Integer.<init>(int value)<n>boolean boolean_expression()<n>java.lang.String.valueOf(int)<n>System.out.println(int)<n>```<n><n>### Instructor: Write this method in your file.<n><n>#### Input: An array with length 5 (a length of 5)<n><n>#### Response: print the following<n>+ - Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you be able to hear a bassoon played in an unpleasing fashion? Choices:  A: orchestra B: baritone woodwind sound C: symphony D: play music E: high school band<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>(C)<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```ruby<n>def my_task(question)<n>  response = question.split.reduce(&:*) + question.respond_to?(:answer)? question.answer : 0<n>  puts response.to_i<n>end<n>```<n><n>or<n><n>```ruby<n>task_question = "Where would you be able see a bassoon played in a displeasing manner?"<n>question = task_question.gsub(",","?")<n>answer = question.split.max - question.split.min + question.split.map(&:size).inject(:+) < answer = <n>task(:my_task, task_question, question)<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:An expressway can suffer from traffic, this traffic gets worse the closer you get to any what? Choices:  A: michigan B: map C: american city D: rest stops E: country<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input(answer):A<n><n>### Justification:<n>The word here would be traffic<n><n>### Input - 2:<n><n>### Response - 2:<n>How many cards do they have?<n><n>### Choice:<n>A<n><n># Input = 6 people in a room - how do you do subtraction to find out how many people is left:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Subscribe to this task<n><n>### Follower: A user who follows a task<n><n>### Assignee:<n>User who was tasked to complete this task.<n><n>### Owner:<n>User who created the task.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Justify:<n>1) 	The task name that I choose was "I want to find out how many cards they have combined and I also want to find out how I can tell how many cards one person have without using addition or subtraction or multiplication and division."<n>1)	This task is related to the real world because it uses addition and subtraction and it can easily apply or relate to this world.<n>1)	The tools and materials that I need to complete this task was a white board, and also paper and a pen.<n>1)	My strategy is to write down some problem then solve them.<n>1)	I chose these materials and tools to use, because I could do subtraction to see how many cards one person has in addition and also write them down on paper.<n>1)	As you can see in the example below, I have 12 cards.<n>1)	Because I know that there is 12 cards, I could write the number down to solve the problem. <n>1)	I used division to see how many cards there are in the entire amount of cards.<n>

B : love. C : laughter. D : smiles. E : tears.<n><n>### Input<n>What color is grass? There are more red than green chairs.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Because the numerator times the denominator equals the number of green chairs the equation should read:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The only two people left were a guy and a chicken. This means there would be a tie for 2nd place. Who won? Who lost?<n><n>### Demo: A tie for 2nd means there are two options, but also means only one of them wins, and the other loses.<n><n>### Response:: One of the tie-breakers is to "flip." Whoever lost this way had to flip a coin. If the man lost the flip, than he lost the race. So technically, the chicken did not lose, since he would have won the race by default.<n><n>### Example 1<n>There were 7 cars in a parking lot when a

For example, if you are presented with the task of computing a percentage (for example, 80% of a number), try dividing the problem into computing the percentage of a whole to one part. This will help you break the complexity down into smaller pieces.<n>- **Use a specific example**. For example, consider the difference between the statement “a/b ≠ c” and the statement “5/7 ≠ 3”. The first statement could apply to any two values, and you do not know which two. The second statement applies only to specific values.<n>- **Focus on the problem** and remember that the task is to solve your programming problem. When you attempt a solution to the problem, **start with a concept** to **represent the problem**, including an illustration that helps you understand the problem. **Start with the simplest solution.** The computer is able to “run the simplest solution” and verify that it is correct. If the simplest solution fails, take this result back to the diagram or your original representation to determine where you erred. **Continue to write code and test it until the simplest solution works**. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:After going for run you have a sense of what? Choices:  A: satisfaction B: flying C: sweating D: falling down E: trip<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>My sister was telling me about this question she answered recently and she was not able to solve it.<n><n>I would help my sister to identify the problem she missed in the given questions.<n><n>1.The question is to calculate the chairs in a classroom.<n><n>So,the question is asking to subtract the white chairs in a class room.<n><n>2.This is a counting problem and to solve that we have to identify which problem.<n><n>We have to identify the relationship between green and blue chairs.<n><n>3.The question is to subtract the white chair.<n><n>So, white chare are one less than the three times of the combination of the green and blue chare.<n><n>Therefore, in the whole question the white chair should be added to the green chairs.<n><n>4.The question says we have to use all the information and solve.<n><n>So the answer is the white chairs in the whole class room is (blue chairs(10))+((green chairs*3)+3white chairs in classroom).<n><n>### Expected response:<n>```<n>Write the solution of the given problem below.<n>```<n><n>### Answer with explanation, if needed<n>[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/-Answered_by-2C97B2)](https://discourse.codecademy.com/t/answered-by-2c97b2/38761)<n><n>### More context about this problem<n><n>https://discourse.example.com/t/1<n>

Choices:  A: suffering B: he was happy C: avoid problems D: unhappy E: end pain<n><n>### Response:		 A: If you want to kill yourself, you are not happy.<n><n>### Reason:<n>Your response should contain a solution and its explanation, including some code.<n><n>### Expected Solution:<n>### I have 4 chickens, but they are not all brown. How many chickens do I have?<n>answer: if the chickens are not all brown, then i only have 4 chickences because  not all brown<n><n>### Exceeded Solution:<n>### Different way to answer<n><n>- if i have more than one chicken<n>if i have only one chicken<n>if none is brow<n><n>### Limitation:<n>- This task doesn't teach how to write if statements.<n><n>### How to Teach<n><n>1) Start with an example of a statement<n>2) give the student some practice<n>3) Tell the student what the program should do<n>4) Ask the student to write the program yourself<n>5) After you receive some code, tell the student what the program does and ask if they have any errors in them<n>6) After you have tested the program, ask the student what they think they did wrong<n><n>### How much it cost<n>- No cost since no teacher<n><n>### How many people can it serve?<n>- None of us<n><n>### Who should do it?<n>- We<n><n>### Who can do it?<n>- If you know programming syntax, you can try<n><n>###### If you want to know how write code, you can try programming, there will have a class and you will teach what your know<n><n>### Prerequisite<n>- 1 or more knowledge of programming syntax<n><n>### What time or days can it be done?<n>- It depends on your free time<n><n>### How long it takes to do? <n>- Around 1 month<n><n>### How hard it is to do?<n>- Easy<n><n>### Resources: <n>- https://www.raspberrypi.org/forums/projects/beginner-projects/<n>- https://www-journals.ecsdl.org/content/5/1/3-31.abstract?<n>- http://www.computersciencedaily.com/4-1d2.jpg<n>- https://www4.ncsu.edu/unity

Choices:  A: study philosophy B: become adult C: ask questions D: further education E: study together<n><n>### Response:		<n>``` <n>Student:A <n>Teacher:D<n>Student:B <n>```<n><n><Details><n>### Instruction<n>What are students trying to solve?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Input: What are students in a chemistry class trying to do together?<n>Answer: Students in a chemistry class are trying to learn more chemistry concepts.<n><n>Input: Which of these might be part of students' discussion: (1) 100 students are planning to further their education. (2) 125 students are trying to become adults. (3) Two students are asking a lot of questions in a class. (4) 50 students are studying together for a unit test.<n><n>Answer: 1 and 2 <n><n><n>### Instruccuion: Write a step-by-step procedure that will help students in a chemistry  class solve the problem.<n><n><Details> <n>### Instruction :What is the step-by-step proces for solving it?<n><n>### Demo :<n>Step 1:Teacher:Ask students how many are furthering their education and how many are studying together.<n>Step 2:Teacher :Ask students how many people plan to finish their degree in five years. and how many plan to finnish in less time.<n><n><Details ><n>### Instruction <n>Wat is the step?<n><n>### Response<n>1 : Add this sentence  "The other students are studying for a university entrance exam."<n>2 : Ask students, "which of these is true? A: 100 students plan to study in universities for five years. B: Only 75 students plan to study at universities for five years."<n>3 : Ask students, "Which of these other sentences best describes the situation? A: It takes only five years to finish a four–year degree. B: A four–year degree takes only eight months to finish."<n><n>### Instruct: Write a two-sentence explanation  on why students need to know this.<n>1 : In an interview with the editor of a popular magazine, the actress Meryl Streep said, “Actors need to be able to understand the world they live in, to be informed of what’s going on.” <n>2: Actors in popular movies

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The lady was getting worked up about the article explaining the uptick in accidents in their area, but her husband was dismissive of it stating that accidents what? Choices:  A: happen to people B: hurt people C: happen anytime D: happen often E: happen anywhere<n><n>### Response:		<n>## You were asked "How many more blocks did he walk than Brenda had?" If you have found two number, you will answer like this:<n><n>**Janet has 9 cards** - we know that Brenda has 150 cards<n>Now use simple math to answer this question. **9** x 4 = **36** <n>**Demonstration**<n><n>```python<n>import math<n><n>n = int(input())<n>if n<=0:<n>  print('negative')<n><n>else:<n><n>  res = 0<n>  for i in range(1,n+1):<n>    res = res*x+3<n>  print(res)<n>```<n>

It means a brothel, and a red light district.<n><n>| C: street corner | Prositution is illegal in all cities in all states.<n><n>| D: corner of two street | Prostitutes usually congregate in the 16th and 18th blocks of streets, or on the “corner,” and work in groups of three.<n><n>| E: brother | The brother is known throughout the United States, and in some European nations as a professional prostitute.<n><n>

Choices:  A: in cinema B: at the park C: martorell D: jeep E: airplane<n><n>### Response:		A: Cinema E: At the A: cinema E: At the Movie<n><n>### Input : I bought a pair of shoes, a notebook, and a backpack. It is between a lower limit and the upper limit if and only if (k <= limit <= n)

Choices:  A: india B: hole C: cage D: habitat E: rain forest<n><n>### Response:		If I wanted to know where a native lemur will be found, I must use my senses. If I smell the animal, it might be because it is close too. If I hear the animal, it might also be because it is close by. If I see the animal, I can also tell where it is close. The best thing to do is to ask someone the closest native lemur.<n><n>### Input; If there are fewer than 500 students in a school, how many students are in a class?<n><n>### Response; If there are fewer students than 500, there will be fewer classrooms.<n><n>### Note; What is the average distance traveled by students who ride 6 buses to school, provided there is a 7-bus line with one less bus being used that day than usual with the other 6 used normally?<n><n>### Answer; 10.875 or ((Bus Length * 6)+((Bus Length*1) - ((Bus Length*1))*1)) /7 = 10.81875<n><n>### Note: If 5% of a city's population travels by bus while 47% drive cars and 48% ride bicycles, what are more cars than bicycles?<n><n>### Solution; 96 *.05 = 5 % of the population who ride buses.<n><n>### Answer- ((Cars+Bicycles) - Bicycles = Bicycles + Bicycles) = 96%<n> <n>

He gives me a lot of money.<n><n>### Additional sentences(s):<n>I'm a little fat.<n>She's a slow writer.<n>I can write very bad sentences.<n>I like to give a lot of money.
