There are as many New Yorkers as Texans. How many people are Texas?<n><n>### Solution (I chose the solution I have learned first)<n>There are 21 people from Texas. How many people are from Texas?<n><n>## Solution 1 <n>The mayor of the town is from New York.<n>There are as many New York residents as there are members from other countries.<n>Every one of them had brown hair.<n><n>There are 29 members from other countries. The mayor is from Texas.<n>There are 4 mayors, and each has brown hair. The number of Texas residents is 29.<n><n>## Solution 2<n>The mayor of the city is from New York or Texas.<n>How many individuals from the town are women?<n><n>There are 57 men from the town. That means there are 106 people.<n>How many men are there in the town?<n><n>Four people. Two of them.<n>The number of children under 10 is 14.<n>The mayor of the village is from New York. Every six mayors are from Texas.<n><n>## Solution (I added it last)<n>The mayor of the nation is from Texas. There are 30 boys and 41 ladies from New York.<n>I counted the number of boys and ladies from other countries.<n>The mayor of town are not all white. 99% of the town's population are white.

Choices:  A: shelf B: cellar C: refrigerator D: cupboard E: grocery store<n><n>### Response:		<n>Let us assume that you are in the grocery or the supermarket.<n>Now, your options are:<n>A) on a shelf on the first floor<n>B) on a cellar<n>C) in the refrigerator<n>D) on a cupboard<n>E) on a shelf in the grocery store<n>You picked door E and door A is too high a choice.<n>Now, your choices are:<n>A) the cellar<n>B) the refrigerator on one shelf or the other<n>C) in the cupboard<n>Now, you pick Door C and door D is too low a choice <n>D) on shelf 15<n>You picked door D and door A is too low a choice.<n>You can use the algorithm that I gave you earlier.<n>Now, your choice is:<n>Your final choice: Door 13<n>Now, you go to the 13th door and you are in the basement.<n>Good luck!<n><n>### Input : The number was 20% of 75<n>My answer: 15<n><n>My response: let x=20% of 45x-50=15<n><n>- I dont know why that is wrong i think my approach is to divide the number of interest in half but i dont know how to do that on the calculator that you provided<n><n>### Instructions: Please answer the below questions. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What can happen in your mind while sleeping? Choices:  A: snoring B: talking C: get cold D: nothing E: might dream<n><n>### Response:		In your example, you stated that all the characters had 80 cards in their deck. That means that the sum of the deck of cards was 80. But you were then asked how many there were in all. But why all? If there are no uncounted cards in the game then 40 cards can only come from one of the individual players. So, this question is wrong.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>This instruction refers to a previous instruction but doesn't repeat anything significant so it may not need to be restated. It will be important to understand what your model did to be able to answer this question. To determine the cards that you had in the first place, the player would count them if they had a deck. From there you would add the cards from the other player. But the instruction itself doesn’t clarify this. Since there is no restatement of the previous instruction, it could be assumed that the two players each had 80 cards for each total deck, not individual card decks. So instead of only including 40 cards for each player we would need to change that calculation to 120 cards.<n><n>Answwer: E: might dream
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where can you purchase food and eat it at tables? Choices:  A: house B: fast food restaurant C: library D: conference E: paper<n><n>### Response:		Which sentence states more information about food and tables? Why does it do so?<n>A: House B: House and library are good places to purchase and eat food.<n>C: At a library, you can eat food at tables.<n>D: Library, houses, and tables are mentioned in the sentence. B contains the only location where food can be purchased.<n><n>### Answer:<n>When we eat food and sit at tables, we are eating and sitting in libraries. House and library are good choices for eating and sitting at tables.<n><n>### Explanation: The given set of choices and the information in the sentence are related to tables and meals. In the given set of choices, “house” alone provides enough information to decide which sentence contains more details. “House” describes a location where food can be bought, eaten, and eaten at tables. The provided sentence includes “houses” and “libraries,” so it provides more information about the subject because it includes a combination of the two.<n><n>### Your response should be 6 to 8 sentences long.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Sarah took poison by accident She found it in the cabinet and. thought that it was what? Choices:  A: drinkable B: junk food C: medicine D: antidote E: nutrient<n><n>### Response:		<n>You have entered an invalid response.<n><n>### Input<n>Janet has 9 cards less than Brenda. <n><n>### Response<n>Janet has 1 fewer cards than Brenda.<n><n>### Output<n>Janet has 78 cards.<n><n>### Justification:<n>Janet's card count is less than Brenda's card count by 2 cards.<n><n>## Task:<n><n>I have a series of numbers that represent the number of cards each person has<n>input: Janet has 6 cards less than Brenda<n><n>Output: Janet has 8 cards<n><n>## Justification:<n><n>Janet has six cards less than Brenda by six. 6 subtracted from six equals two.<n><n>Since: Brenda - six = six - six - six, Janet has eight (six - six).<n><n>## Task 2<n><n>I have a set of letters that represent the names of people in a class. <n><n>input: Pete walked 6 blocks from his house to his bus stop<n><n>output: Pete walked 10 blocks to the bus stop<n><n>##Justification:<n>Pete walked 6 blocks to his bus stop, so an extra 4 blocks were added.<n><n>## Task 3<n><n>I have a list of numbers that represent the people in a classroom.<n><n>input: <n>The green chairs are 2 times as many as the white chairs.<n><n>output: <n>The  green chairs are 4 times as  many as the white chores.<n><n>##Justification<n><n>Because 2 x 4 = 8<n>

Then:<n>Your bill = $368.45 for food +<n>$52.84 for eating out + <n>$100 at target +<n>$7.74 for online shopping +<n>$11 for interest +<n>$16 for insurance =<n>773.33 total<n><n>### Response Examples:<n><n>### Input Your credit card bill is 773.36 if you spent 340 at Starbucks, 125 at Target, and you have interest of 12.25<n><n>### Input

Create a variable called "number" that stores the number "45"<n>2. Store your name and phone number in a string variable called "name"<n>3. Print out the number stored in the variable you created, also print out the "Hello" string<n>4. Print the "Hello, " variable with the string of your name and contact number afterward<n>5. Store your name and surname, city, and age in a new table, the variable that you used earlier in the program "name" and the variable "number" are used to construct the data structure.<n>6. Read the table of information you created as an object and use show() function to display the variables<n>

Choices:  A: charming B: space shuttle C: house D: train station E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explanation:<n>I will explain the concept with this example :A train has a closed atmosphere of CO2 which has been breathed by the many people but they are breathing the purified atmosphere by the filters of the train after this the train atmosphere will change and it will breathe the clean air that has been breed by a few  people in the past<n><n><n>### Input Choices:Choose  an integer from 1 through 15. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where does someone not happy to take their car? Choices:  A: down a river B: city C: repair shop D: parking lot E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		<n>In this question, you need to write a Python program that asks for a number and prints out whether the number is a multiple of 3 when 2 digit number starts from 2 or greater and greater than 9. Then you need to explain the program with comments.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```python<n>input = input("Enter number to test:")<n>a=10<n>if input<a:<n>    print("Invalid number")<n>    quit()<n>x=input<n>#if x<50:<n>#    y=input<n>#    a=5<n>#elif x<100:<n>#    a=1<n>#else:<n>if x%3 == 0 and x>50 and x<1000:<n>    print("Is multiple of 3")<n>elif x%3 == 1:<n>    print("Not multiple of 3")```

Below is an example of an initial value that allows you to quickly set up your output.<n><n>```csharp<n>    int counter = 1;<n>    // This is your outer loop that<n>    // counts the days.<n>    for (int days = 1; days < 720; days++) {<n>       // This is the inner loop to count the minutes.<n>       for (int minutes = 0; minutes <= 60 * 60 * counter; minutes++) {<n>          // This statement must be inside both loops,<n>

Choices:  A: celebrate B: have party C: hear crowd go mad D: create success E: reproduce<n><n>### Response:		Success would be reproducing if one has been trying to procreate.<n><n>### Input<n><n>What is the square root of 948?<n><n>##### Answer<n><n>The square root of 9 4 8 is the positive real number that, when squared, yields the prime number 9 4 9. In decimal form it is equal to  9 0 8 3 7.<n><n>##### Input:<n>What is the square of a rational number?<n><n>##### Solution<n><n>##### Input<n>It takes 7 days to take a picture of the moon. <n><n>How many seconds in 7 days?<n><n>##### Demonstration<n><n><n>To 7 days, divide 7 by 86.<n><n>**In order to get 86 you will need to subtract  7 x 86.<n>**<n>```R<n>x <- 7<n>x -= 86<n>print(x)<n>```<n><n>##### Solution 1<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The expression y = 2x + 7 expresses a function in which the<n>y-coordinate is equal to 2 times a given x-coordinate plus 7.<n><n>### Answer:<n>(y = 2x +7)<n><n>Let the function name be "brownies baked" where the<n>number of brownies baked is equal to 2 x the number of people present + 7. You've<n>decided to bake 24 brownies this evening. If you have a party where there are<n>12 people present then how many brownies will there be?<n><n>(2x12+7=24)<n><n>### Show an example of using the function to find solutions to problems:<n><n>### Output:<n>The problem shown above.<n><n>Output:<n><n>```R<n>> y=2x+7<n>> y(3)<n>[1] 9<n>```<n><n>### Input and output:<n>The problem shown in the examples.<n>```R<n>> x= 3<n>> y(x)<n>[1]  9<n>```<n><n>The expression shown:<n>```R<n>> 2x+7<n>[1] 2 2 4 4 6 6 8 8 10 10<n>```<n><n>##

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where is one likely to purchase listening vinyl? Motor bikes are much better for your wallet.

If 6 people are selected at random, what is the probability that this selects 2 women?<n><n>### Response-Demonstration: If there are 5 women, then 2 wives, then there are 3 people. If there are 4 women, then with 2 women, then there are 6 people. This is 2/3. That is, there are 6/5  people. This is 8/5  people. <n><n>> The probability if it is the ratio of favor to unfavorable is 8/5.  That is, there are two people on the woman side, and there are five people on the unfavorable side.<n><n>### Input and Response: What is the largest number that can be formed with 6 coins, if all coins are the same? This means that among the 6 coins each coin can not be counted twice. The answer of coins with two different values can not form a number larger than this answer, because they 2 coins will be counted twice.<n><n>### Response Demo: <n><n>Assume that there are 6 different values of coins, and then they are even.<n><n>> The number of coins of one value is equal. The coins to be counted in the process of counting 1 2 3...n are counted only once.<n><n>For example, when two coins are counted 2 2 3, the number of unique counts is 2, the total number of counts is 4, and 4 is unique, and it is 6 times less than the unique counts.<n><n>> Thus, it is a unique value. <n><n>### Input - Demonstration: The first number is 9. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Too many people want exotic snakes.  The demand is driving what to carry them? Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write a program that has the correct output based on what is chosen by the user. Also your program needs to have one or more input of your own creation.<n><n>### Input<n><n>*   A. If they want anything to carry them they will need to bring it out into the ditch.<n>*   B. There are too many snakes to carry in any place. So they will end up being sold in the shop.<n>*   C. They will end up in some other part of the world such as north america where there are more places to place them.<n>*   D. You will need to take them to pet shops and see what kind of offers you get.<n>*   E. If you put them into pet shops it will just be another place where they will have more places to be sold than put in a ditch.<n><n>### Output<n><n>*   A will not be a good suggestion unless they want to be in a ditch. But if they just want to be transported around the store they can put them all on a belt or in a basket.<n>*   B might be a good choice if they are selling more exotic snakes out of their pet shops instead of just the regular snakes. So they have the choice of where to shop.<n>*   They might need a new place to sell snake, that is if they have too many snakes to sell in just pet shops.<n>*   They can decide to either have the pet snakes or have the exotic snakes, but not both. It will be a hard decision to make and might have to bring the snakes to other places such as the ditch.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:WHat do cats get into when they are ripping things apart? Choices:  A: dog's mouth B: floor C: garage D: trouble E: nature<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explain:Janet has 9 cards. Brenda has 6 cards. Mara, who has 134 cards, is twice as many as Janet. This was answered by adding Mara's number to Brenda's number. This also added 40 cards to the 6 cards that Brenda had. The answer, 211, comes from adding Mara’s number, 134, to Brenda’s number, 6.<n><n>Pete walked 5 blocks to the bus garage, 20 blocks to get his bus, and 5 back to his house. His answer, 50 blocks, comes from adding the two middle numbers, 50 and 20.<n><n>Green seats make up 3 times as many seats as the blue seats in a classroom with 10 blue seats. There are 13 fewer than the sum of the green and the blue seats, meaning the green seats are 13 times as many as blue seats. Since that doesn’t quite work, and “1” times more than “blue” is obviously incorrect, the answer is 67.<n><n><n>Which of the following is a letter B<n><n>### Instructions:Choose a letter from the alphabet and use your knowledge of math to figure out which letter it is B, Y, or Z!<n><n>### Response<n>### Instruccion:Elija una letra de la alfabet y usal su conocimiento de matematicas para adivinar cual es la letra B, Y, Z.<n><n>### Response C:La respuesta es C.<n><n>### Expand:El alfabeto va desde A, donde la letra Y se encuentra en el centro, hasta Z donde la letra Z de esquivar hacia la derecha y la Y es esquivar hacia izquierda.<n><n><n><a id='input_question_and_response22'></a><n>### Instruction and Response:<n>Use any equation from the previous exercises as your prompt and answer any equation from the previous exercise. It's completely up to you! <n><n>### Instructio:Usa cualquiera de las ecuaciones de los ejercicios anteriores como la promocion y responde a cualquiera de las

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Bob's feet hurt from running barefoot on the hot pavement.  I lost his shoes, didn't know where they landed, and had to run from the corner store to his home.  About where did he run? Choices:  A: a bed of nails B: town C: attractive consistent look D: city block E: ground<n><n>### Response:		Answer: 300 feet<n><n>Comment: Hey there, hope you are doing great!<n><n>I really hope someone takes the time to review and give me some feedback, I've never made a program that has had to check for a variety of answers! I really want to improve my skills.<n><n>Any help would be great, thank you.<n><n>Comment: I have updated my answer.<n><n>Answer: You could use the below function to get the answer.<n><n>\begin{code}<n>public static double getDistance(String instruction) {<n>    String[] split = instruction.split(" ");<n>    String instructionStr = split[0]<n>                             + instruction.split(" ")[1];<n>    for (int i = 1; i <= 5; i++) {<n>        instructionStr = instruction.split(" ").replaceAll("([a-z]+|" + "\\d+)", "\\1");<n>        if ("1".equals(instructionStr)) {<n>            return 1;<n>        } else {<n>            if (i == 5)<n>                throw new RuntimeException(InstructionException.class.toString());<n>            else<n>                i++;<n>        }<n>    }<n>}<n>\end{code}<n><n>If you are given more than 5 numbers, you can throw `RuntimeException`.<n><n>And the caller may look like something like this.<n><n>\begin {code}<n>    double value = getDistance("Janet has 9 cards " || " more than Brenda. "){<n>        // Your logic here<n>    }<n>\end{code}.<n><n>Of course, this logic is quite imperfect. But you can get a general idea about how to solve this problem.

For example, the answer to “how many cards do they have” is 211 and not the expected 151. The other problem is similar. They are not accurate because they ask you how far Pete walked from his house, not how much farther Pete walked from his home. To answer the question, we need to know what the actual distance was.<n><n>The answer to the question of how many chairs are in a classroom is 67 and not 27.<n><n>For example, if we take “A” and combine it with “B” we get “AB”. This gives us B. If we combine “A” and “C”, we will get “AC”. That will give us C. This gives us one for A, one for C, and another for D.<n><n>## Resources<n><n><n><n>## © 2021 Trilogy Education Services,  a 2U, Inc. brand. All Rights Reserved.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What type of home is most likely to have an attic filled with historical items? Choices:  A: top of home B: older houses C: victorian house D: own home E: material<n><n>### Response:		A<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:How is someone who loves their TV likely to feel about their remote? Choices:  A: attached B: nostalgic C: companionable D: likely E: close<n><n>### Response:		 E: close<n><n>---<n><n>```r<n>data = read.csv(file.path("data/question-two.csv"))<n><n>### This is the data table<n>head(data)<n><n>### Question 2<n>data$QuestionTwoAnswers<n>```<n><n>### Question Two<n>Question Two asks the user to perform some arithmetic, but there are different numbers of values in the data set. This causes incorrect answers. The values below are used in Question Two.<n><n>```<n>Question Two Values<n>```<n><n>|   Question Two | Card | 1 | Card | 2 |<n>|----------------|-----|-----|-----|<n>|Brenda           | 25  | 7  | 6  |<n>|Mara             | 90  | 9  | -10 |<n><n>```r<n>### Question Two Analysis<n><n>data$QuestionTwoAnswerAnswers == "Brenda, 9" + "Mara, 20"<n><n>### Question One Analysis<n># 211 = 9 + 9<n># Question One asks the user how many cards all the people have in a specific set. The data contains values in card one and card two. The user needs to calculate how many cards are in a separate set. The data for question one contains<n><n># 9 = 25 - 16<n># 10 = 25 + 25<n># 20 = 10 - 8<n># 41 = 14 + 27<n><n>### Question Three Analysis<n># 25 = 15 + 10<n># 56 = 4 - 12<n># 67 = 23 + 44<n>```<n><n>## How is it working?<n><n>### Question one<n><n>```<n>Question1 <- function(values) {<n>    sum((values))<n>}<n><n>Question1(as.matrix(data))<n>```<n><n>## Question 2<n><n>```<n>Question2 <- function(cards = 9:25, colors = c("blue", "green", "white")) {<n><n>    for (i in 1:length(cards)) {<n>        print(cards)<n>    }<n><n>    for (colors in colors) {<n>        print(colors)<n>    }<n>}<n>

Choices:  A: coal or wood B: fire C: lava D: house E: solar energy<n><n>### Response:		Choices: Answer: D, but could be an A, B, or C<n><n># Tally Question<n><n>This section shows how to solve a specific type of problem. The type of problem that you will need to solve is called a tally question. A tally question requires you to count the total of two or more integers. For example, if you count up how many marbles are in one jar, that is a tally question.<n><n>Follow the steps to solve these tally questions.<n><n>Write an equation to represent the problem.<n>In the equation, one side shows the total of how many marbles you have that side. The other side shows how many marbles we pick with each of those picks. The equation represents the number of picks that you have to make to find every last marble that you've picked up.<n><n>If the number of marbles that you've picked is less than the number of marbles in the jar, then you can count up every one of those marbles to solve the problem.<n>If the number of picks in the equation is greater than the total in the jar, then add the remaining marbles to the total that you've already counted. Use this approach with every marble that you're left counting.<n><n>In the steps to solving the problem, make sure to include the final answer. You only have to include the final answer if you can't solve for it later in the step.<n># Task<n>This section has a tally question that you need to solve. Follow the steps to solve it.<n><n># Instruction:Solve the following multiple choice question:<n><n>Sherry has a dog, a cat, and two fish left in her house. Sherry is going to get rid of two more pets. If she gets a new dog, how many more pets will she have left?<n><n># Demonstration<n>I wrote an equation for Sherry's problem. Let's count how many marbles we're left with if Sherry picks them all up. We'll solve by counting with each pick we make and we'll find every last marble with this solution.<n><n>Let the marble picks be \(x\). We want to count to the total of the two picks plus one. Let that be \(y\).<n><n>Solving for \(y\), we get<n>\[\begin{align*}

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you go if you didn't feel like baking a cake yourself? Choices:  A: theater B: refrigerator C: bakery D: grocery store E: oven<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A: B C: D E: C D: A E: D<n><n>### Instructions: Choose the best option.<n><n>### Inputs: <n><n>```<n>John is planning to paint the walls of his house. He bought 8 gallons of paint last week and 15 gallons this week. How many gallons of paint did he buy altogether?<n><n>```<n><n>### Choice E: 55<n><n># Solution<n><br><n>`(8G + 15G)` === `(8 + 15)` === `23G` == `55 / 2G` === `27.5G` <n><n>```<n>Tina is painting her house. She bought 10 gallons of paint last month and 15 gallon this month. How many gallons did she buy altogether?<n><n>### Choices: <n><n>```java<n>35 gallons<n>25 gallons<n>15 gallons<n>40 gallons<n>55 gallons<n><n>```<n><n><n>### Response A:35 Gallons<n>### Why:<n>`((10+15) / 2) / 1G` === `(25) / 1G == 25G` //25<n><n><n><n>### Instructiion<n><n>```<n>Marian is on her way to the store to buy some groceries. She needs to buy at least one pound of coffee, two pounds of fruit, and three pounds of tea. How much food does she need to buy altogether?<n>```<n><n>> [Option E: 10 pounds](http://bit.ly/2yu3iNh)<n><n>### Output:<n><n>> <ul><n>>   <li>Answer is 10 (pounds)</li><n>>   <ul><n>>     <li>The sum of the values in the input options.</li><n>>   </ul><n>> </ul><n><n>### Output Description.<n>The answer is a direct result of this equation.<n><n>```java<n>2Pounds + 3Pounds + 1Pounds = 6Pounds //6Pounds<n>```<n><n>`(2P+3P+1P)/1Pound` === `((2+3+1

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Bob and Boris were standing in a queue at the grocery store.  They were standing in place.  The line was fast, but the children in front of them were loud.   They were what? Choices:  A: frustration B: being annoyed C: delays D: irritation E: out of order<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is letter C (Delays)<n><n>### Explanation:If 'they were walking in a line that moves very slowly' then it means that the queue was very slow.  Therefore, 'fast' cannot be the answer.  The line was actually fast, because it was moving very quickly, but the children were loud, so it wasn't what the question says:<n><n>### 'What are Boris and Bob feeling?'<n><n>### Answer:The correct answer is 'Delays' -- They are feeling delayed.<n><n>### They are not angry (a)<n><n>### The line is moving fast (b)<n><n>### They weren’t sure where they were in the line (d)<n><n>### Nothing is wrong with them (e)<n><n>### Their children are in the line and therefore they are frustrated (f)<n><n>###  They are in line at a grocery store at the moment, so there is an assumption that they don't know what they are feeling.<n><n>### Reference:<n><n>[Reference] (Susan B. (author) (2016). Math practice test: elementary 2 (Tutorial book). Inkling Learn LLC.)[1]<n><n>## Challenge<n><n>### Write an expression that computes the following sum _______________________.<n><n>Example<n><n>_3 + 5 + 7_<n><n>_Result: 15_<n><n>Input:8*2<n><n>### Write a code statement that subtracts 40 from the value of ______.<n><n>Input: 12345<n><n>### Summary<n><n>* [The instructions from below:](./instruction.md)<n><n><n><n>### Assessment<n><n>* [Add up your scores](./questions.md)<n>

Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>import random<n><n>ans = ['A', 'E']<n>for x in ans:<n>    print ('')<n>    print (x,end='')<n>    print ('')    <n>    choice = input ("What do you think the answer is? : ").lower()<n>    if choice in ans:<n>        print (x,end="")<n>    else:<n>        print ("Wrong. Try again.")<n>    print ()<n>```<n><n>

Choices:  A: school B: office building C: house D: hotel E: centre<n><n>### Response:		school <n><n>### Instructions:For the first part of the activity, respond with one question per person in the list. How much money do they have altogether?<n>    Answer: 69.19.<n><n>### Demo<n>   Let n = Shelby's money and k = Chloe's money, then answer is 104 + n - k.<n><n><n>### Input Give this code (https://www.hackerrank.com/challenges/ruby-puzzles/problems/array-average-python) a run<n>    <n>Two or three kids go to a library. They have the same amount of money, but one book will cost X coins one is Y coins, but two are Z coins. If they spend their whole amount of money, how much money do they in total?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>First, let u be the money of one kid, and v be the money of two other kids. Let u, v be two different variable because kids have different money.<n>```<n>u1 + u2<n>```<n><n><n><n>```<n>10 / u10<n>20 / v20<n>30 / u30<n><n>10 / 10 = 1<n>20 / 20 = 1<n>30 / 30 =<n>```<n><n>### Input (link:https://www.hackerearth.com

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some large pieces of paper that are not for sale? Choices:  A: cabinet B: computer printer C: suitcase D: office supply store E: artist's studio<n><n>### Response:		Computer printer. Ex: A printer is a machine that makes an image by transferring ink from ink cartridges to paper to make a printed page. The image could be text or pictures or both. The ink cartridges can contain black ink or color ink or both. So it is a machine and has an image (paper) that it produces by making text or pictures (ink cartridges) with a cartridge or cartridges (paper) and printing it. <n>A printer can print, but a writer cannot<n>A printer can print a book or novel or comic books or brochures but a writer cannot. A printer can print a map and directions and brochures but a driver cannot. A printer can even print a whole book or story but a teacher cannot.<n><n>### Example: <n>#### Incorrect: "I made the map for you on the computer, but I'm not a computer."<n>#### "I am a computer and I can make the map for you."<n><n>#### Incorrect: <n>#### "The printer made me on the printer."<n>#### Incorrect:<n>#### "I made the printer for me."<n>#### Correct:<n>#### "I typed a message and sent it to a printer.  A printer then printed the message for me."

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Why would professionals playing sports not be able to compete? Choices:  A: pain B: mudslide C: sweating D: injuries E: rain<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the choice that does not complete the scenario.<n><n>### The correct answer is _______.<n><n>### Instrections:Choose the option that best completes the scenario.<n><n><n>* <n>\[ \hat{p}^{\text{true}}_1 : = 0.2\]<n>\[ \hat p_2 : 0.1.\]<n>\[ \hat {p}_X : = \frac{1}{5}\]<n><n>### In order to get to the grocery story<n><n>### A: the driver must have driven less than \(3/5\) kilometers.<n><n>### B: the driver will only have driven \(3/5\text{km}\) if the engine is not running when the car is started.<n><n>### C: the driver will only use \(3/5\times 1000\) kilometers worth of gas in the trip to the grocery store.<n><n>### D: to get to the grocer store, the driver will have to travel \(2,500\times 10^4m\)<n><n>### E: the grocery store is less than one thousand kilometers away<n><n>### Response<n>![](image/Exercise1-1.png)<n><n><n>* 1. <n>You are 5000 feet over sea level and travel 500 feet up. What does this expression represent in terms of your starting elevation?<n>*\(*\) I am now at<n>> 5000 foot.<n>and then went<n>> 2500 foot,<n>what is my final elevation?\*<n><n><n>### Response 1:<n>\[ \text{1.595 feet} \] for the final elevation<n><n>### Response Explanation 1:<n>From the starting altitude of \(5000\mathrm{m}\), you will have to ascend \(500\mathrm{ m}\), which is the expression on the left. The expression on the right-hand side states starting altitude of \(2500\mathrm m\).<n><n>### Input 2: What is the elevation?<n><n>You travel 6000 feet up.<n>> Then you go<n>> 3000 feet down

Evan and Michael are the next two oldest. The two youngest are Adam and Andrew. Which is the fourth oldest child?<n><n>  Answer: Andrew<n><n>  Output:There is a way to count 650 people from the beach if:<n>  650 people are in line for the ice cream.  Each person takes a turn so the same person does not get in line twice.  There are enough ice cream cones for every one in line if every person takes a turn. How many people are in line for ice cream?<n><n>### Output:<n>The man standing at the bus stop is not from Chicago, as he is 2000 miles from home. He is 20 hours and 45 minutes away from home. He takes a plane at 5PM that day that arrives two hours later at 7PM to his home. What time does he leave for the bus stop?<n><n>  Answer and Explanation:<n>2000 is multiplied by 2 and divided by 2 with the remainder being 7:20.<n>5PM is the 5th of the month so 2000*2=4000, 4000/2 becomes 2000 again and 2000/2 is 1000 or 7PM. 7PM would be his arrival time.<n><n>  Input:If there are 650 people on the beach, how many can have a snack if there are 185 chairs and only two of them are reserved?<n><n>  Answer C: If there are 65 people in the line, 2.5 can have a snack. 185 is 5 times 37 and 37 is 2.5 times 15<n><n>  Input:The man standing at the bottom of the stairs is 6000 miles from his home. He is 5 hours and 15 minutes away from home by plane. He takes a plane that leaves at 5PM and arrives at 7PM at his home. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Choices:  A: villa B: spacecraft C: hall D: palace E: hotel<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple question.<n><n>## 1) You can choose to be happy if you just don’t look around too much.<n><n>## 2) Being depressed is the best possible thing that could’ve happened to you.<n><n>## 3) You will feel better when you find someone who makes you feel so lousy you hate your life.<n><n>## 4) You should stop looking at the problem altogether.<n><n>## 5) When you go for a walk you get depressed.<n><n>## 6) You will find something to feel depressed about if you stop looking for it.<n><n>## 7) You can escape depression by thinking deeply about your life situation.<n><n>## Explanation of Correct Answer:<n><n>There are three possible answers, and one answer is correct: “You should stop looking at the  problem altogether” is correct.<n><n>## Examples of Incorrect Answers:<n><n>Incorrect: “You can choose to be happy.”<n><n>Incorrect: ”Being depressed is the best that could have happened to you.”<n><n>Incorrect “You will feel better in every way when you find someone who can make you feel so lous yourlife.”<n><n>Incorrect, “You should stop looking for the problem.”<n><n>## Explanations of Incorrect Answers<n><n>The first three incorrect statements are incorrect because they are true in the extreme. These statements are clearly irrational. For example, it is irrational to say that being depressed is the best thing that ever happened to someone. The fourth statement is incorrect because it is a statement of fact, but it does not help to explain the reasoning. The fifth statement is incorrect because it does not offer any explanation. The sixth statement is incorrect because it offers no explanation. The seventh statement is incorrect because it presents no evidence to explain the problem.<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: make music B: believe in god C: give speeches D: complete sentences E: build houses<n><n>### Response:		The only people that can correctly answer this question is you.<n><n>#### Explanation <n><n>I created this project after getting annoyed at my roommate who is a non-believer. I would always say, "God Bless you". He would reply, "Yeah, whatever". Later I started to realize that he doesn't believe in God. I thought about this after he said this one time. He would go on to say, "And people that live together are like married people, so why do married people ask each other every morning, "Why are you leaving me? and "Are you happy?". So then I had an idea. I am going to create a speech therapist program that will make every sentence that I ask, "Why are you saying that and "Are you happy?" I will say "A: make music", "B: believe in god" "C: give speeches" "D: complete sentences" and "E: build houses". I would love to see this in action.<n><n>#### Expected Output<n><n>Response to question: B - Believe In God<n>Because of the statement, "A: make music" and "B: believe in God" the program decides that the correct answer of the choices is "B: Believe In God".<n><n>Response to question B: Are you happy?. The program determines that the statement "C: give speech" is the best.<n><n>You can see the following screenshot for reference as the question was answered correctly.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:James was cooking s stew in his apartment kitchen.  Where might he look for a potato. Choices:  A: restaurants B: casserole C: root cellar D: pockets E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		The response is the value of ‘C’. As the value is not mentioned, it is to be assumed.<n><n>### Input : The time and date are 9 pm on 28th June. Time: 9 pm Date : 28th June<n><n>### Response : The response is the value corresponding to ‘date’ and the value of ‘time’is to be determined. So, the response is the value of the ‘time’ column. It is 9 from the options.<n><n>### How do we determine the response in cases where there are no suitable options?<n><n>There are various such options which can be taken in order to identify the answer. In general, such answers can be identified by using the ‘Precision, Recall, and F1’ formula. The other measure can be ‘Weighted F1’ formula.<n><n>### Precision and Recall Score Calculation<n><n>The ‘Precision, recall, and F1’ are the measures used to determine the precision and recall scores for the tasks. It is an accuracy score which is a metric used to determine the ability of the machine to classify. As such, Precision and Recal score the accuracy of the machine while the F1 score is the average value.<n><n>### F1 and Weighted F1 Score Calculation<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n><n>### Response:		A)Cools down<n>### Instruction 2<n>### Demonstation<n>Input:  The sun was out and the sun was increasing rapidly<n>Answer: A) The sun was increasing rapidly<n><n>Input:   The sun is out and the temperature had dropped precipitously and quickly.<n>Answer: B) The temperature had dropped precipitiously<n><n>Input:   What the sun doing?<n>Answer: D) The sun is heating up rapidly<n><n>### Input 3<n><n>### Demonsration<n>Input:   The snow is melting quickly out in front of your car.<n>Answer: C) You need to get your car away from your car<n><n>Input:  What is the sun doing?<n>The sun was increasing rapidly.<n><n>### Response 3<n><n>## Demonstration 3<n>Input:      The sun was out and it quickly dropped to zero degrees and rapidly and precipitously.<n><n>Answer: D) quickly dropped and quickly dropped<n><n>Input:       What is the temperature outside? It is quickly cooling down in a rapid manner out in front of the car.<n><n>Answer: E) quickly cooling down<n><n>## Input 4<n><n>This input is just one line of input.<n><n>Answer: B) Cools out<n><n>## Demonstation 4<n><n>Answer: A)  The sun was out for sure<n><n>Answer: E: Cools out<n><n>The air gets cooler and colder.<n><n>A: The air gets cooler and cooler<n><n>Answer:E: Cools out.<n><n>## Demonistration 5<n><n>Input: The snow is melting.<n><n>Input: The weather is getting warmer.<n><n>Answer: A: It is getting warmer.<n><n>Input: What does the weather say?<n><n>Answer: B: The weather is cooling down.<n><n>## Demostration 6<n><n>Input: The temperature has dropped precipitously and rapidly.<n><n>Answer: A. The temperature has dropped precipitation.<n><n>Input:   If you see the weather is cooling down, what does that tell us?<n><n>Answer: The temperature dropped to zero.<n><n><n><n>## Input 7<n><n>Input: The air is getting warmer. The air is cooling down. <n><n>## Demostation 7<n>Answer A: It's getting war

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The graveyard was important to build, where should it be built? Choices:  A: arlington B: church property C: out back D: every town E: cemetery<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>***<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Choose the right question.<n><n>## Instruction:<n>There have been 40 visitors at the restaurant in the last hour. Half were male.<n><n>1. How many were male if 8 were female?<n>1. How many more male were there if female were 16?<n>1. Of the 16 who were not male, how many were female?<n>1  How many visitors have been to the restaurant since it opened at 11 am this morning, including the 40 people above.<n><n>### Responses:<n>1 16+8= 24<n><n>### Instructor Notes:<n>Notifications: "The first two choices are correct, but the last two choices do _not_ accurately describe the situation since the last half had 40 people, which is not enough to make the two statements true for all male and female. This is similar to the way that people often inaccurately describe a situation by saying "It is either true or not true." The "or" is not required, the situation just needs to be true for all cases.<n><n>### Correction:<n>The sentences in a correct answer should be in the form:<n><n>1. How (many) can you answer the question correctly? (Choose 1 of the 3 statements and describe how to determine whether the answer to the question is correct.)<n>1. How (may) you answer the question correctly, if (condition)? (Choose 1 statement and describe how to determine if the answer to the question will be correct if the condition is met.)<n>1. How do you correctly answer the question with no restrictions? (Choose 0 or 1, depending on how the question might be able to be answered correctly without restrictions.)<n><n>### Correct:<n>1. How may you answer the question correctly if the last half had 8 males and 16 females?<n>1. How may (you answer) the question correctly if the conditions are stated above?<n>1. How can you answer the question if the last half had either too few (40) or too many (100) males?<n>1. How did you answer the question correctly last week, when they last had (100 or fewer) males?<n>**The problem requires a person to accurately determine the number of

How are we feeling?<n>There are multiple choices. I can choose A, B, C, D, or E.<n><n>### Answer Choice A: exhausted<n>"Exhausted" means completely tired after doing physical activity. So, I do not choose answer choice A.<n><n>### Choice B: lonely<n>"lonely" means you are sad or feel alone. So, I do no choose Choice B.<n><n>### Response B: worked all day<n>"Worked all day" means that you spent your entire day working. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The sound waves bounce off the ceiling, walls, and floors of the room and build in strength.<n>

The answer, though, is (B). Such a certificate is most likely to apply to a restaurant.<n><n>### HINT<n>

Choices:  A: run programs B: play games C: control model D: power down E: reason exists<n><n>### Response:		Answer must be "A", programs, power down.<n><n>### Input : After the election, a new president was elected and an inauguration ceremony took place where the incoming president was sworn into office. What is an example of an inauguraton or induction?<n><n>### Response : Powerup ceremony or swearing in ceremony.<n><n>### Challenge-1<n>Input : If you have one person working half a day on Monday and then half of the next day on Tuesday, what is the total work that person does in one day?<n><n>### Solution: I used 30 days as the total number of working days. On monday he worked for 8 hours in total. But on next day he had to do two half day. His total work for Monday and Tuesday is 8+2*4=24. In one day he did 24 hours work.<n><n>### Solution 2: We can also solve this problem like that he did 8x2x=16 hours work total in 30 working days.<n><n>### Output<n><n>**Input:** The population of an island is 10. Three families migrate to the island. the number of people in each family is 3, 4, and 2. Write a expression that gives the total number of people on the island.<n><n>**Solution:** 10 + 3+ 4+ 2<n>**Output: 10**<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The children saw superman fly overhead, what did they exclaim as a result? Choices:  A: ouch B: skip C: enjoyed D: awesome E: watch television<n><n>### Response:		<n>![](/img/questions/superman_exclamation.jpg "The children saw superman")<n>  <n><n>### Solution:<n>**Code to answer the question:**<n><n>```python<n>from math import ceil<n>from operator import mul, add, truediv<n><n>def exclamation():<n>    children_sees_superman = input()<n><n>    if children_sees_supe_man in ['A: ouch', 'B: skip', 'C: enjoyed', 'D: awesome', 'E: watch television']:<n>        return children_sees_supeman<n>    else:<n>        return "Invalid answer."<n><n>print(exclamation()+"")<n>```<n><n>### Input::A man walks 5 blocks north from a bus garage. He takes the same bus 8 blocks south from his new location. He travels in the same direction in exactly double the distance as he did originally. How far does he walk in all?<n><n>### Input to answer the question:<n><n>- A man walks 5 Blocks north from a bus garare<n>- take a bus 8 blocks southward<n>- walk in the same direction in an even bigger distance<n><n>The answer is 8<n><n>### Solution to the task:<n><n>````python<n>from math import truediv<n>#define variables<n>bus_distance = input()<n>bus_bus = input()<n>man_start = int(input(""))<n><n>if man_start == 0 and (bus_bus * 2 * bus_distance < 3):<n>    result = ceil(bus_bus * (bus_distance - 8))<n>    result = result + 16<n>    print (result - bus_distance + 8)<n>else:<n>    print "Invalid answer"<n>````<n><n>### Result:<n><n>```text<n>man walks 5 blocks in the north<n>take a bus that rides 2 blocks in the south<n>get back on that same bus and ride it 2 blocks in the north<n>man walks and same direction and in double distance<n><n>```<n>

Choices:  A: department store B: school C: garden D: office building E: house<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input:"You have two books that weigh 12 ounces each.  The books are twice as heavy as the pencil." What is the heaviest object? Choices: A: pencil B: books C: pencils D: books and pencils E: pencil and books<n><n>### Response B<n><n>### Question:You have two bags of corn that cost $3. 50 each.  Your grandfather gives you another bag of corn that was harvested from his farm.  The bag of corn from the farm costs $1. 50 more per bag than the other two.  The bag you are given is three-quarters of the weight of all three bags of corn. In ounces, how tall is the bag from the farm? Choices: A. 13 ounces B. 18 ounces C. 30 ounces D. 61 ounces E. 82 ounces<n><n>### Response"C".The bag of corn from the grandfather is 18 ounnes, so it is three-quarters of all three bags. We know all the weights:  $3.50+3.50+1.50= $8.50, so we know the average weight of the bags: 60 ounces. So the bag from the grandfathers farm is 18/60 or 3/5 of the weight of the other bags, or 18 ounes.<n><n>### Input"You have two jugs that each hold 21 fluid ounces.  The jugs are 2 ounces heavier than 30 bags of corn. The bags of corn are three-fourths of what you weighed the two jugs in ounces." How many ounces of fluid does each jug hold? Choices: A 26.78 B. 42 ounces C.43.64 ounces D 24.62 ounces E.47.25 ounces<n><n><n>### Response:"C"<n><n>As we know the weight of jugs, we can find out the weight of the bags<n><n>$21+21+21=

Your job is to develop a command-line calculator program for performing basic operations.  Use the following prompts in your program to solicit the necessary inputs for each computation.  Use a data file to keep accumulating inputs for a given operation.  Remember, input files have a file extension (*.dat).<n><n>#### Example:<n><n>Enter your first choice.<n>>   A  <enter><n><n>Enter your second choice.<n>>   B  <enter><n>Enter your third choice.<n>>   C  <enter><n><Enter the result><n>>   D  <enter><n>End result is A.<n><n>2. The results should be displayed to the command line.<n><n>3. The file should be readable only within the same directory and it should be accessible to the CMD.EXE application. In other words, a file, a file location, or a drive location can be provided as input to the program.<n><n>4. The input prompt should be displayed until a user responds.<n><n>5. Any value in the prompt should be considered to be an input to the program when a user presses the corresponding key.<n><n>6. The input file should be displayed in the CMD.EXEX application.<n><n>7. The file has to be removed after the result is printed.<n><n>8. Use the CMD application to test the program.<n><n>9. Use the.DAT extension in the prompt to indicate that a user should enter numbers instead of a word.<n><n>10. To make it easy to understand by the user, write the instruction using different colors.<n><n>11. Use only one color when printing the prompt or the final result.<n><n>12. You can use a loop statement to print a large number of similar computations by simply incrementing each output.<n><n>13. Use only one line of prompt for each computation, even if the computation uses different calculations.  <n><n>###  Task:<n><n>For this task, your job is to create a command line and word calculation program that prompts for calculations and displays results to the screen.<n><n>You need to use a command-line prompt and a word processing software of your choice.<n><n>1. Use only one file extension (*.dat) in the prompt for entering comput

Janice's day is looking busy. She needs to make a baking mix, clean the bathroom, vacuum, mop, and do several other tasks like these. She can remember a checklist but she thinks she could use a graph to visualise her tasks and see how quickly everything is getting done. (For example, she knows she can't mop and make a cake at the same time.)<n><n>**Choices**<n><n>1. Make a checklist of all the tasks she can think of that need to get done today.<n><n>2. Make a graph. The first task is at the top of the graph. As she completes it she moves to the left until she gets to the last task. Then she fills in the graph. She will have to go in order. Each task is a square.<n><n>3. Make a checklist. The tasks can be completed in any order. If there are 20 tasks the list will have 20 squares.<n>    <n>How many squares does she need to draw if she chooses to make a checklist? 20<n><n>### Inst

You will also need to include a second case that will detect when the input is less or equal to 4.<n><n>2. When the input is 5 or above, be sure to detect that in your second nested if statement and don't forget to include the answer for this second case.<n><n>3. If you include the wrong answer for the first case, the program should not answer at all.<n><n>If the answer is 4, the program should answer 22.<n><n>If the input is 5, the program should answer false.<n><n>If the program does not answer the question correctly, a hint will be provided.<n><n></div><n></details><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The man tried to run, but he could not. He could that he could only move by doing what? Choices:  A: stand B: go quickly C: walking D: stand still E: walk slowly<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Output:<n><n>### Example Output<n><n>Given input "Susan is ten years old. Her friends Jane and Anna are both forty years old"<n><n>Process:<n><n>Step 1 - Create a new variable to hold answer<n><n>step 2 - Create a empty list to store elements from input string<n><n>step 3 - Create new variable to hold number of digits<n><n>Step 4 - Create new variable to store loop variable<n><n>Step 5 - Create a loop variable<n><n>Step6 - Print the user answer<n><n>Step 7 - Convert elements in the input string into list<n>Step 8 - Loop through the list with input string<n>Step 7 - Add the values to the sum of the list<n>Step 8- Print the sum of the list in the end of the for loop<n><n>Step 10 - Print the final result<n><n>Example OutPut:<n><n>```<n>24 //Answer to the multiple choice question:<n>```<n><n>### Sample Code<n>```<n>var sum=0<n>var counter=0<n>var ans=''<n>var numIn = `Susan is ten <n>    years old. Her friends <n>    Jane and Anna are <n>    both forty years old`<n><n>while(numIn!='') { //looping the input string<n>    if(numIn[:i]==' ') { //checking the spaces in user string<n>    counter=counter+1<n>    sum=sum+counter<n>    is=index(numIn,'')<n>    <n>    ans=ans+str(counter)<n>    <n>    <n>    }<n>    else{<n>        <n>       numIn=substr(numIn, 1, is- 1)<n><n>       i=i+1<n><n>    }<n><n>    counter=0<n>    sum=0<n><n>}<n>ans=ans+str(sum-3)<n>console.log(ans)<n>```<n>![](/img/1.png)<n><n><n>

When I exercised, it gave my body a chance to recuperate. After I start to get into my rhythm, I will relax and start to enjoy my self and start feeling better. That energy that i start to gain will have my system ready to start working again.**<n><n>#### **E:** **Do exercise. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. (This is where students should code their own responses)<n><n>`$$`This code is where students can review their previous answers.<n><n>`$$$`This code is the end of the question prompt, but does not end the lesson module.<n><n>`$$$$`This code is the ending of the lesson module. (No more questions will come after this code)<n><n>`$$$$$`This code goes at the end of the instruction as a "This ends all".<n><n><n>###### Question:<n>Question1 (The first line of the prompt to ask a question)<n>Question2 (The first line of prompt for students to submit responses to a question)<n>Question3 (The first line

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:You can share files with someone if you have a connection to a what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:When you play around with your dog they will have? Choices:  A: alive B: health C: fun D: playing dead E: black<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>    print("Let’s check if you understand the input. This is the example you were given:<n>    - The sum of two times 3 and 7 is equal to 20<n>    Is that your response?")<n><n>    while True :<n>       answerChoices = 'A','B','C','d','E'<n>       ans= float(input('Your input') ) #Enter the value you like, like 2*3,and get the answer<n>       ans = 100/ans<n><n>       if ans in answerChoices:<n>           ans = ans+5 #If you entered 3 you get ans = 8. Add 5 make ans = 13.<n>           print(ans)<n>           break<n>       else:<n>           print("That is not the right ans. Can you re-check yourself with the input and ans?")<n>           continue<n>```<n><n>### Explaination:<n>In the first part, my logic is if user enter the wrong ans, I will ask him/her to press the re-check again. If they enter again, it means they got it wrong. If they press  'yes'-they got it right, if they press 'no' which mean they enter again the wrong ans, then I will give it to the user.<n><n>In the sec. part, I want to make a if else code. So if user enters a=b+7 I will display print(ans) which will be answer 'b' plus 7. So that if users enter 3 they get the answer 10. Then I want my code to add 5 to the result ans, which means user's input 3 is equal to the input 2*3 in the question. That why I multiply the ans+5 I make the right ans=2*3=13.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:How does getting paid feel? Choices:  A: income tax B: satisfaction C: sorrow D: ocean E: bill collectors to happy<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>Answer = input("Your answer:" + "\n")<n>```<n>Answers = [<n>    ["a", "sorrow"],<n>    ["b", "satisfaction"],<n>    ["c", "income tax"],<n>    ["d", "ocean"],<n>    ["e", "bill collectors"]<n>]<n><n>for x in Answers:<n>    if Answer in x:<n>        return "correct"<n><n>Answer = input("You answered: " + "\n")<n><n>if Answer == b or Answer == c or r[0] == c:<n>    print ("answer" + " is correct")<n>else:<n>    print("answer" + " is incorrect")
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where do bees congregate with red flowerS? Choices:  A: trash can B: honey C: bouquet of flowers D: rose garden E: field of flowers<n><n>### Response:		How many times is the number of red flowers less than the number of bees?<n><n>### Expected Outcome: If A is the correct answer, then the answer should output 0. If B is the correct answer, the answer should output 3. If C is the correct answer, to the answer should output 2. If D is the correct answer, answer should output 1.  If E is the correct answer, than the answer should output 6.<n><n>### Hint: Hint 1: If the number of red flowers is $43$ and the number of bees is $23$, then the number of bees minus the number of bees divided by number of red flowers is three. Hint 2: You have eight bees less than you have 18 red flowers, and the remainder is six. You have 21 red flowers, and there are six times less than red flowers than there are bees.<n><n>### Outcome:<n><n>### If E is correct, answer should output 6<n><n>### If B is correct, answer should be 3<n><n>### If C is correct, answer should come out to 2<n><n>### If A is correct, answer should equal zero<n><n>### If D is correct, answer should produce 0<n><n>### Output sample:<n><n>### 6<n><n>## Hint: Write the program. If we make this mistake, we will be able to recover.<n><n>### Note: In this lesson, be sure to write a response that handles each question properly. You will not pass the exercise if you miss a problem.<n><n>### Exercise:<n>How many times is the number red flowerSes less than the number of bEes?<n>```cpp<n>#include <iostream><n><n>using namespace std;<n><n>int main()<n>{<n>  int flower, bees, remainder;<n><n>  cout << "\n\n" << "\n\n";<n>  cout << "INPUT:How many flowerS does the woman have? Choices: A: trashB: honey C: a bouquet of flowerS D: a rose gardenE: a field of flowers\n";<n><n>  cout << "OUTPUT:How many times is the flowerS less than the bees if the the number of flowerSes were 43 and

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The city's community garden was demolished for yet another what? Choices:  A: wasteland B: ocean C: desert D: parking lot E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Demonstration: Enter the command `answer`. Your response should be similar to the example: Answer: Flower garden<n><n>#### Helpful Hint: For this question, do not look at the choice. Instead, think about the question. "What was demolished?" is an action. For this question, the action was that of demolishing. This leads to the answer choice of 'Flower' since a flower garden is the intended purpose for the community garden.<n><n>### Input<n>#### Demonstratioon: Enter the command `pause`<n><n>### Time Limit<n><n>5<n><n>### Memory Limit<n><n>10M (10.01.2020), 11M(04.28.2020)<n><n>### Tips<n><n>You can choose to use the same answer as your partner, but we would like to see your responses to these problems.<n><n>If you're unfamiliar with the command `answer`, read `p.2` and `p.3.`<n><n>### Attach Files<n><n>To read the instructions for this problem, look at `p.3`.<n><n>{% assign answers_files = site.data.answers.files %}<n>{% assign p = 'p.3' %} %

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:John was punching and punching at the wall but succeeded only in bloodying his knuckles. This was bad.  He would be unable to hold his tools if he injured what? Choices:  A: hostility B: anger C: nose D: fists E: hands<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**A** is correct.<n><n>We can assume that by 'his knuckles' we mean what would it be if 'John' was a single, collective person, rather than many individual people.<n><n>We can also assume that in order to be unable to hold his 'tools' John has to somehow use his hands without using his knuckles (the injured ones).<n><n>An interesting way to approach this is to ask the question: "How do we use our hands with knuckled?" or "How do the actions John took use his hands?"<n><n>That would indicate that 'John" used his hands in some form of action in conjunction with the actions of punching or punching the wall.<n><n>Since John can not use his hands, he can not use one or many 'actions' to hold his tools.<n><n>Therefore 'B' is incorrect.<n><n>John can not use his fists, because his hands can not be injured because they are the instruments he uses to hold his tools. Without his fists he can not hold his tools.<n>    <n>If John's fists are injured then it is not 'John' who loses his ability to use his tools. In fact, he uses the fists less then he uses his hands, but he can still use his hands.<n>    <n>Therefore the other choices are incorrect.<n><n>Therefore the answer is "John" can not use his tools because he can not use his hands.<n><n>### Input :  What is the smallest five-digit number that ends in nine? <n><n>### Instructions:Your answer may be a number, a word, or a phrase. If your answer is a number, you may use any number of decimal places. Explain how you obtained your answer.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>If we write our number as "1" and "0" digits, we need to find the number of the last digit in the smallest number that is five digits long and ends in a 9.<n><n>The longest number we can have is "0999". There are five digits that can be used to represent "9999", but we need to use 5995 or less.<n><n>We know that in a number made of digits representing digits between 0 and 9 that the largest number to add to 5995 is 6 and it can be written
